Headline: Barron's(1/8) New Package, Same Barron's
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Edwin A. Finn Jr.   I could dream up a dozen reasons why we've moved to this new format. It's easier to handle. It looks snappier. It will save money on newsprint, and so forth. But the real reason is that our big sister publication, The Wall Street Journal, is adopting a narrower format, so we at Barron's must go to this shorter size.   Like the Journal, Barron's is printed on a terrific network of 19 Dow Jones presses around the country. That's why we can reach homes and newsstands virtually nationwide on Saturday mornings. This rapid delivery system is unique among American magazines and, even in the age of the Internet, we don't want to give that up. It helps us to stay on top of the markets until they close Friday evening, and markets remain key to all the analysis, judgments and predictions you'll find in each week's Barron's.   I was concerned that readers wouldn't like the new format. But last summer, in a series of focus groups, readers were either unconcerned or actually happy about it. They called it "easier to handle," "more modern" and "more like a magazine." All good.   Reader reaction also was overwhelmingly positive to the redesign we did at Barron's 20 months ago. That's when we added summaries above the headlines, more white space, and a box on most feature stories called "The Bottom Line," highlighting the investment prediction being made. We're happy to say that all of those changes have been retained.   What worried readers most in last summer's focus groups was that Barron's might be changing in some fundamental way. I can tell you that we are not changing our basic mission. We are different from magazines like Forbes or Fortune or BusinessWeek, and we will always remain so. We think we're smarter, of course. But what cannot be disputed is that, unlike so many other magazines, Barron's spends the majority of its editorial energy figuring out what's going to happen next. That's what our readers want from us.   When a publication shrinks each page by 20%, it's only natural that readers would wonder what's being left out. We have added some pages, to avoid cutting a full 20% of the space, and we have reduced the size of headlines and the white space around each article, so as not to lose substance. We have also trimmed our statistics, removing anything from the Market Laboratory section that was being used by less than 4% of our most avid statistics readers. Any stats that have been removed can be viewed free at Barron's Online. For a list, see page M18. Throughout the section, we've added charts with captions written by Barron's editors. (see accompanying illustration -- Barron's Jan. 8, 2007)   In all the research we have done, readers told us that they appreciate judicious editing, but they don't want stories to be cut sharply. We've tried to comply. Cover stories and articles about companies will not shrink, while some columns will be trimmed about 20%. On average, the reduction in word count is around 10%.   To sum it up, this is the same Barron's you've come to know, just in a new format -- one we hope will prove more convenient.   None of this means Barron's doesn't change. We have changed gradually over the years, reflecting developments in the markets and in reader interests. That explains our stepped-up coverage of hedge funds, exchange-traded funds, private banking, separately managed accounts, financial advisers and top CEOs, to name a few topics. In today's issue, too, you will see a substantive change. Across from this letter is Streetwise, a new column by Mike Santoli. For the past four years, Mike has penned our popular Trader column. Look for his keen market insights, elegant prose and smart investment ideas weekly in Streetwise.   Our outstanding options editor, Kopin Tan, takes over for Mike on Trader. The talented Steve Sears will now write the magazine's Striking Price options column, while our insightful capital-markets expert, Randy Forsyth, will once again author the Current Yield column. Both Steve and Randy also have excellent columns featured free during the week on Barron's Online. Check them out at www.barrons.com.   Please let us know what you think of our changes -- in both style and substance. You can contact me at editors@barrons.com or at Barron's, 200 Liberty St., New York, N.Y., 10281.   Edwin A. Finn Jr.   Editor and President   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  January 06, 2007 00:03 ET (05:03 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: HK Hutchison Chmn Li: Worldwide 3G Subscribers Over 14M
Story: HONG KONG (Dow Jones)--Hutchison Whampoa Ltd. (0013.HK) has over 14 million subscribers for its third-generation mobile business globally, the company's chairman, Li Ka-shing, said.   "Despite intense competition in the global 3G arena, we have increased our subscribers worldwide to over 14 million and we are moving towards achieving our operating targets," Li was quoted in a transcript as saying during an internal meeting of Cheung Kong (Holdings) Ltd. (0001.HK), which holds 49.9% of Hutchison. The transcript of the meeting, which was held Friday, was provided by Cheung Kong.   Hutchison started 3G operations in the U.K. and Italy in March 2003 and later launched 3G in markets that include Australia, Austria, Hong Kong, Denmark, Sweden and Israel.   Hutchison, Li's ports-to-telecommunications conglomerate, last reported in August that it had 13.5 million subscribers for its 3G business globally.   Li, the Hong Kong billionaire, was cited in an interview with Forbes magazine earlier this week that he believes 3G operations will be cash-flow positive by next year.   "Our losses have been narrowing every year since 2005. In 2008, we should at least be cash flow positive," he said, according to a transcript of the interview on Forbes.com.   Li also said in the internal meeting that the group's other core businesses - including property, ports and retail - "continued to steer a course of steady growth."     -By Aries Poon, Dow Jones Newswires; 852-2832-2332; aries.poon@dowjones.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  January 06, 2007 02:54 ET (07:54 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(1/8) Quarterly Mutual Funds Review: ETFs For Commodity Fans
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Andrew Bary   An exchange-traded fund launched friday will give investors a play on the hot agricultural commodity markets. The PowerShares DB Agricultural Fund (DBA) was one of seven commodity ETFs from the duo of Deutsche Bank and PowerShares Capital Management that began trading on the American Stock Exchange.   The PowerShares agricultural fund is the first of its kind, meaning investors who want exposure to the sector don't have to delve into the actual commodity markets. The new agricultural ETF will have a 25% weighting in four commodities: corn, wheat, soybeans and sugar. Each of those commodities advanced in 2006 with the exception of sugar. Corn starred, rising 80% to almost $4 a bushel, driven by ethanol demand.   The grains fell back last week, but bulls like Byron Wien, the former Morgan Stanley strategist who now works for Pequot Capital in New York, thinks corn could hit $5 this year, while soybeans could rise to $9 a bushel from the current $6.65. The PowerShares funds, unlike the liquid streetTRACKS Gold Shares ETF (GLD), will get exposure to the commodity markets through futures contracts. The  streetTRACKS ETF owns the physical metal.   Another new PowerShares DB fund that could gain acceptance is linked to base metals. That fund, PowerShares DB Base Metals (DBB), will focus on aluminum, zinc and copper, each of which will account for one-third of it. No other exchange-traded fund offers a base-metals play. The base metals surged in 2006, but were hit hard last week as copper fell about 12%, to $2.54 a pound.   The other five new funds track energy, oil, precious metals, gold and silver. The precious-metals fund is 80% gold and 20% silver. These funds join the PowerShares DB Commodity Index Tracking Fund (DBC) which already trades on the Amex. The original streetTRACKS gold ETF, has helped spur the gold price because it has sucked 15 million ounces of gold, worth $9 billion, out of the market. If they prove popular, the agricultural and base-metals ETFs could lift those commodity markets.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  January 06, 2007 00:05 ET (05:05 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(1/8) Streetwise: Pacing The Invisible Line
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Michael Santoli   Wisdom resides near the border of patience and stubbornness. Yet when it comes to investing, the market alone determines where that frontier lies.   Market skeptics last year, by their account, were practicing patience, waiting for the present bull market to act its age and succumb to a serious setback by conforming to a time-steeped tendency to break a hip in mid-term election years.   As it turned out, the bears' and defensively invested bulls' steadfast stance against big upside was exposed as stubbornness. Stocks levitated from midsummer through yearend, defying doubters and the sundry hedge funds conditioned to play a narrow range-constrained market.   By some measures, the velocity of the Dow's 17% sprint from its July low to above 12,500 matched the pace of this bull's initial surge from the bear-market lows in early 2003. This is extremely youthful behavior for a mature bull phase entering its fifth year.   People of many years' seasoning can curse youth or chase it, or both. A woman in the film When Harry Met Sally . . . describes a male friend's new, younger girlfriend this way: "Pretty. Thin. Big [breasts]. Your basic nightmare."   The bears' plaint of 2006 was similar, assailing what most find appealing: The indexes' near-vertical run higher, its immunity to adverse economic news, a refusal to pull back to furnish better buy points, the broad involvement by most stocks and the full participation of the largest blue-chip stocks. And, yes, many chased it higher.   Most things that drive stocks -- liquidity, corporate earnings, interest rates, inflation -- don't suddenly shift with the change of year. Still, age matters. Eventually the sweet crispness of a bullish theme softens to an overripe condition. But how best to measure age, in days or in the distance traveled?   Ned Davis Research reports that this is easily the longest-duration bull market without at least a 9.6% retreat. The next longest was the one from late 1990 to early 1994. The S&P 500 dropped 8% last spring, the slimmest high-to-low pullback of any four-year market cycle since 1934.   Yet over that prolonged stretch, the magnitude of the market's appreciation has been unspectacular by historic standards. Up about 66%, the Dow has gained less than it did in the next five longest bull markets.   So, as 2007 gets under way, we have a market that's been unusually placid, in part because of copious liquidity, and that very cash-aided steadiness emboldens greater risk taking across asset classes. Corporate bond investors are more accommodating than a five-star concierge; emerging-market stocks are the world's darlings.   The valuation of U.S. stocks is middling by historic standards, and will not in itself stand in the way of greater gains. Corporate earnings have been heroic. The buyout game is at some unknown point along the path from sweet spot to overdone frenzy. Until that one loopy deal spurs the debt market to cry "Uncle," it's a net positive for stocks.   In sum, the ingredients of a market melt-up are in place if the big-picture concerns of excess debt, a housing recession, the abiding inflation threat and a wild-card financial "accident" are forestalled. Yes, those are big "ifs."   All this makes it an environment quite like the one that has prevailed since the fleeting scare last summer -- only with the indexes 17% higher since July, much less constructive skepticism toward stocks than there was then and the bull market another six months older.   Bulls still hold claim to the benefit of the doubt for now, even if last week's choppiness segues into an overdue stiff pullback. They believe they are simply being patient, waiting for the market to catch up to what they consider fabulous fundamentals. For a time, this patience ought to be rewarded. Until, of course, that invisible line between patience and stubbornness is crossed.     It wasn't easy for a telecom company to have a lousy 2006, but Sprint Nextel (ticker: S) managed it -- shares down 11% with the sector up 30%, missing earnings forecasts three straight quarters, a messy merger integration in a year when the AT&T-BellSouth deal was acclaimed as a masterstroke. All this was more than enough to lose friends on Wall Street, where only a third of the analysts now recommend Sprint stock, as opposed to 70% of them pushing AT&T (T).   But turnaround seekers should take heart in the sour sentiment, as well as the stock's cheapness versus the industry, based on cash flow. Sprint, with a $56 billion market value and less debt than its peers (too little, some say), is buying back $6 billion in stock while investing $3 billion in local WiMax wireless data networks, a major gamble on future wireless data and entertainment traffic.   If it pays off, great. If not, and the core business keeps struggling, the stock's not expensive, and Sprint as an acquisition target is already being bandied. All of which shifts the risk/reward bargain in investors' favor.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  January 06, 2007 00:03 ET (05:03 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(1/8) Tech Trader: Weather Alert: Headwinds Are Gathering Force
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Bill Alpert   Goldman Sachs' tech analysts described their early 2007 "positioning" in a report last week. They are positioning themselves out the door.   After a 27% rally in the latter part of 2006, says Goldman's gang, tech stocks will probably pull back in the first half of this year. Typically, the first-half decline in tech unwinds about half of the preceding year-end rally. In fact, for the past five years tech stocks have given negative returns for the first three quarters of the year.   Computer hardware stocks have had themselves a nice run, notes Goldman's Laura Conigliaro. The brokerage firm's index of hardware stocks rose 43% from last summer's trough. In the past five years, those stocks have slid an average of 17% in the beginning of each year.   Results for the December 2006 quarter shouldn't be bad, particularly given the weak dollar. Investors ought to sell into any strength in tech stocks, as companies report their December quarters. Lexmark International Group should report a solid December quarter, for example, bringing the printer manufacturer's earnings per share for 2006 to $4.15. But at a recent price of 72, Conigliaro thinks the stock (ticker: LXK) trades at an undeserved valuation premium to Hewlett-Packard (HPQ). She moved Lexmark to a Sell last week, with a target price of 54. By contrast, she thinks that H-P's shares could move from current levels of about 42 up to 47-which would leave them at 18 times her calendar 2007 earnings estimate of $2.62.   The Lexington, Ky.,-based Lexmark has improved its profitability by moving away from the low end of the inkjet printer market. But inkjet sales are slowing generally, says Conigliaro, and Lexmark is losing shelf space at retailers. Meanwhile, its sales mix in laser printers is moving in a less profitable direction.   While Conigliaro is partial to H-P, and also IBM (IBM), she notes a growing headwind for their sales of the large computers known as servers. That comes from virtualization, which is a software trick that allows multiple applications to run on a single processor. Virtualization lets data centers get higher utilization of their server hardware. Combine virtualization with the increasing number of processor cores being packed on a chip by Intel and Advanced Micro Devices, and you might see why Conigliaro wonders if customers will need to buy fewer servers as the years go by.   Enterprises are really moving virtualization from test environments into data centers. That's why the leading seller of virtualization software is on fire: the VMware subsidiary of EMC (EMC). The unit's sales could rise almost 60% this year to $1.1 billion, according to the forecast of Sanford C. Bernstein's Toni Sacconaghi.   If virtualization becomes a challenge for server sales at H-P and IBM, needless to say it will be an even stiffer challenge for the third- and fourth-place server vendors, Dell (DELL) and Sun Microsystems (SUNW).     The Goldman analysts also downgraded one of their Buys to a Neutral, namely Seagate (STX), the disk-drive maker. This volatile Scotts Valley, Calif., company is up almost 30% since September to a recent $26. That's about 15 times the average First Call estimate for Seagate's June 2007 fiscal year earnings and 10 times estimates for the following year -- multiples that don't seem pricey. . . unless you're talking about a disk-drive maker. The demand environment for drive storage is pretty good, what with videos accumulating on every home's hard drives and high-definition video making its market entry. Businesses keep buying storage arrays from the likes of EMC. And even in the sullen market for PCs, notebook sales are doing decently.   Unfortunately, there remain a number of competitive disk-drive suppliers. Besides Seagate, there's Western Digital (WDC), Samsung Electronics, Toshiba and Hitachi. Illustrating the industry's one-upsmanship, Friday Hitachi said that it will be the first to ship a disk drive that can store a terabyte of data. That's a billion pieces of information and enough, says the company, to hold 250 hours of high-def programming. The terabyte drives should arrive at retailers by the end of March, says Doug Pickford, director of marketing and product strategy for Hitachi Global Storage Technologies. After the March quarter, Hitachi hopes to start supplying the makers of set-top boxes and digital video recorders with a version of the terabyte drive that will have (wink, wink) "bedroom acoustics."   With a $399 list price, Hitachi's terabyte drive reduces the raw cost of drive storage to less than 40 cents a gigabyte, from about 45-50 cents a gigabyte for today's largest-capacity drives. Till now, Seagate has enjoyed bragging rights to the world's most-capacious drive, with a 750-megabyte product. In themselves, terabyte drives won't quickly become a huge-selling product for drive makers. Computers still account for 80% of hard drives sold, and the market researchers at iSuppli say that the capacity sweet-spot for PC drives today is 100 to 160 gigabytes. Aside from PC gamers and media pirates, the early demand for terabyte drives should come from video recorders.   But Friday's terabyte announcement shows that drive makers can't rest on their laurels. In reaction to Hitachi's terabyte announcement, Seagate vowed to have its own terabyte drive in the first half of this year and promised to beat Hitachi in supplying such products in volume. So the drive business will stay competitive.   I commiserated with Hitachi's Pickford about his industry's unremitting pace. "The disk-drive market is a clear testament to a free-market society," he said with wistful pride.     Merck just completed its $1.1 billion acquisition of Sirna Therapeutics -- a little company that's gotten a good start in RNA interference technology. Inside the body's cells, this technique can block the RNA messenger molecules that instruct a cell to make a particular protein. In many diseases, problematic genetic instructions lead to the overproduction of a substance that harms the body. Last year, a Nobel Prize went to scientists who had discovered the RNA interference approach.   "RNA interference is the most important discovery in biology since Watson and Crick discovered DNA," Sirna CEO Howard Robin told me, in all modesty.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  January 06, 2007 00:05 ET (05:05 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(1/8) Quarterly Mutual Funds Review: -2-
Story: Although many of the American funds continue to outpace their peers, two of the largest, Washington Mutual Investors and Investment Company of America (AIVSX), have trailed them in recent years.   With $84 billion in assets and seven counselors, Washington Mutual is categorized as a large-cap value fund. Its three- and five-year returns rank in the bottom half of its Morningstar peer group, although its 10-year record is in the top 30%. It should be noted, however, that this fund generally has outpaced its benchmark, the S&P 500, over the past decade.   "Any one of our given funds, over 20% to 25% of the time, tend to lag the appropriate benchmark," says Armour. "But most of our funds, over 75% to 80% of the time, have done better" than the benchmark.   Armour says that many of the companies doing well coming out of the stock downturn in late 2002 and early 2003 -- particularly those with a commodities or raw-materials bent --  were not applicable for the Washington Mutual fund to invest in because of its emphasis on dividend-paying stocks.   It's also faced a headwind because it has a heavy dose of domestic large-cap names.   Investment Company of America's three- and five-year returns also rank in the bottom half of Morningstar's large-cap value group, although its 10-year performance puts it in the top 20%. Its $88 billion in assets are overseen by nine managers. Its proclivity for very large companies has hurt performance. (See the table on the preceding page.)   Many of the firm's other large funds have superior long-term track records, including EuroPacific (AEPGX), Capital Income Builder (CAIBX), Capital World Growth & Income (CWGIX) and Income Fund of America (AMECX). Ironically, one of its smallest funds, New World (NEWFX), with $11 billion under management, ranks near the bottom of its category, based on three- and five-year returns.   "We've been able as an organization to do well for over a long period because we are long-term-focused," says Armour. "Everything we try to do, day in and day out, is oriented for the long term."   That approach will be severely tested if the American Funds' largest members continue to pull in cash from investors at the torrid pace of recent years.   But with a formidable investment system, an enviable culture and an estimable roster of analysts and portfolio managers, the funds' adviser, Capital Research and Management, seems up to the test.   Steering a supertanker is extremely challenging, especially in uncharted waters. But it's easier when the helmsman can draw on three-quarters of a century of experience to figure out what to do.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  January 06, 2007 00:07 ET (05:07 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(1/8) The Trader: Hey, What's Up With A Down January?
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Kopin Tan   January gets a bum deal as months go. Short days. Cold nights. A hangover after December's excesses, and all that pressure to set the tone for the new year.   Okay, both the days and nights have been unusually warm this year, but the pressure's been a bit much, even for a January. With investors counting on economic growth that would be modest enough to prompt the Federal Reserve to cut borrowing costs in 2007, the government delivered news on Friday of just the opposite, or at least what the market interpreted as such. The release of a report showing robust job growth in December sent both stocks and bonds tumbling amid concerns the economy is reaccelerating.   Nor did the signs that pointed to a softening economy, like the week's steep slide in oil and copper prices, mollify investors. Without paying too much heed to the annual flip of the calendar, performance-chasing fund managers who had to run after the 2006 rally now get a fresh 12-month window to earn their keep. And they could -- for now -- wait for better openings to pounce.   The Dow Jones Industrial Average ended the week down 65, or 0.5%, at 12,398. The Standard & Poor's 500 fell 9, or 0.6%, to 1,410. It was the second decline in three weeks for both benchmarks.   Technology stocks proved the lone standouts. Despite losing half the week's gain Friday, the Nasdaq Composite Index ended the holiday-shortened week up 19 points, or 0.8%, at 2,434; it has risen in four of the past five weeks. The Russell 2000 index of small stocks fell 12, or 1.5%, to 776.   The Nasdaq's defiance amid a broad retreat is a divergence that bears watching. A tech resurgence would auger well for the market, while a "dead-cat" bounce after a flubbed December would spell more woe. The advance of the Nasdaq 100, for example, was powered by the likes of Intel (ticker: INTC), a Dow dog last year that drew bargain hunters and renewed Street optimism; Cisco Systems (CSCO); Dell (DELL) and big biotechnology stocks. On the bright side, this could suggest a willingness to put money at risk, notes Jason Goepfert of www.sentimentrader.com. But the lack of corroboration from small and emerging-market stocks robs this argument of some conviction.   If risk-taking is not yet in vogue, profit taking certainly is after last year's rollicking rally. The construction-equipment company Terex (TEX), which has rallied more than 1,000% in four years (including a 43% spurt last quarter alone), sold off after Citigroup flagged its rich price tag and a peak in demand in the non-residential construction market.   To cite one example of a common exercise, Merrill Lynch strategist Savita Subramanian screened for stocks that have outperformed their sectors to a degree unexplained by fundamentals. The goal: identify big winners that could face selling pressure in the new tax year. The "run is done" list includes DirecTV Group (DTV), General Motors (GM), Kohl's (KSS), Safeway (SWY), Boston Properties (BXP) and Deere (DE).   The prospect of more buyouts and shareholder action that would lift stock prices propelled buyers. Another round of takeover speculation fingering Bristol Myers Squibb (BMY), already fetching among the highest price-earnings multiples in its sector, spurred brisk buying of its bullish call options.   Shares of Home Depot (HD), highlighted by Barron's just last week as a potential buyout target (see "Home Depot, Lowe's are Poised to Nail Down Gains," Jan. 1), popped after the company's board ousted CEO Robert Nardelli. The stock has long screened as cheap on the basis of earnings, cash flow and book value. While it gave back its gains in Friday's selloff, mounting shareholder pressure -- some prominent holders now are angling for a restructuring of the board -- should speed the home-improvement giant's move to harness its value.   With the U.S. no longer the only engine driving global economic growth, it was perhaps apt that the year began with stateside traders waiting and watching. While U.S. markets were closed Tuesday for President Ford's funeral, overseas stocks got a nice headstart. The race to catch up briefly sent the Dow to an intraday record above 12,580 on Wednesday, but the vaunted average and its traveling companions sputtered when notes from a December meeting showed a Federal Reserve still alert about inflation but increasingly chary of economic weakness.   That about-turn had pundits predicting a return of volatility, even though the benchmarks ended the day little changed. Last year, the S&P 500's cumulative daily returns -- the sum of each daily gain or loss, regardless of direction -- was a muted 228%. The average daily move of 0.47% -- compared with, say, 1.27% in 2002 and 0.84% in 2003 -- was the smallest since 1995 and marked the third consecutive year of tiny daily variations, says Robin Carpenter of www.CarpenterAnalytix.com. A fourth quiet year isn't without precedent, although average daily moves that had stayed below 0.5% from 1992 to 1995 began to climb soon after as the market grew more volatile.     Energy stocks couldn't have gotten off to a worst start. A freakishly balmy winter and rising inventories sent crude oil down 7.8%, its biggest weekly drop since April 2005, to $56.31 a barrel. Oil-and-gas-related shares were pummeled.   The ferocious selling and breach of key support levels has technical analysts bracing for further skids. But the correction also provides an opening for longer-term investors. Despite its blazing run over the past three years, energy remains relatively unloved among sector strategists. Valuations are cheap by various metrics. According to Henry McVey, Morgan Stanley's chief investment strategist, the ratio of forward price-earnings multiples in the energy sector relative to the S&P 500 has now sunk to levels last seen in November 1982 and July 2001 -- both periods that were followed by strong and sustained rebounds.   At just 1.5%, the sector's projected profit growth in 2007 also is the most subdued among S&P sectors. Compared with, say, 18.2% for information technology and 11.2% for consumer-discretionary companies, energy's low bar leaves room for expectations to be exceeded.   To be sure, investors are wary of penciling too much into their growth forecast since profits swing with oil prices. But most analysts continue to use conservative oil-price estimates. Stable and higher oil prices aren't out of the realm of possibility heading into seasonally strong months between February and April when energy stocks historically have outperformed the market.   Robbert van Batenburg, director of research at Louis Capital, is among those who expect oil prices to rebound strongly in 2007. Global demand shows no signs of abating, while instability in the Middle East and uncertainty surrounding April elections in Nigeria, responsible for 14% of U.S. crude-oil imports, all can drive spikes.   Oil companies also have been traditionally conservative in deploying their cash stashes, and stock prices could get a boost should these laggards begin catching up to the market. Energy companies generated 15% of the operating cash flow of S&P 500 companies last year, second only to the 21% chipped in by financials. Yet, energy ranks a distant fourth among sectors in recent share buybacks. Goldman Sachs expects energy to lead other sectors in generating dividend growth averaging 13.4% over the next three years.   Within the sector, big drillers and services companies already have been roundly embraced by sell-side analysts and swaddled with Buy ratings, but refiners and producers seem less beloved. Falling oil prices hurt the whole sector, but the major integrated giants like ExxonMobil (XOM) and Chevron (CVX) typically benefit from the ensuing flight to quality.   What investment strategies paid off most in the past year? Simply picking the 50 stocks in the S&P 500 that had the least analyst coverage would have produced a return of 24.6%, says Merrill Lynch, whose quantitative strategists compared the results of some 40 different stock-selection ploys. The outperformance of companies largely ignored by Wall Street firms was hardly what one might expect a sell-side broker to point out, but there's no denying the outperformance in recent years of small, out-of-favor stocks that failed to make the Street's radar.   Meanwhile, picking stocks based on a low ratio of price to cash flow generated a return of 23%. High dividend-paying stocks climbed 21.7% -- and that's before dividend yields were included.   A similar study by Birinyi Associates also suggests that under-the-radar value stocks might offer the best profit potential. In fact, buying stocks with the lowest projected growth rate over the next five years earned an average return of 26.5%, Birinyi found.   Picking stocks on the basis of dividend yield, or estimated price-earnings multiples both produced returns just shy of 20%. None of the nine strategies examined lost money in 2006. Or maybe it was the market's rising tide that simply lifted all.   ---   E-mail: kopin.tan@barrons.com   ---                  VITAL SIGNS                                Friday's        Week's     Week's                                 Close        Change     % Chg. Headline: Barron's(1/8) Plugged In: Cisco Makes A Savvy Deal
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Mark Veverka   A stronger market for initial public offerings, particularly of bigger companies with evident growth potential, may have compelled Cisco Systems to pay a rich $830 million for IronPort Systems, a privately held messaging-security company. But the deal, one of the first big tech buyouts in a year that could see many more, is likely to pay handsome dividends for the networking giant and its shareholders.   The IPO market has thawed considerably in the pastyear, to judgeby the number of offerings in 2006, and the flood of filings in the second half of the year, says IronPort's corporate adviser, Brian Roberts, a managing director at Evercore Partners (ticker: EVR). Evercore, founded 11 years ago by Roger Altman, former deputy secretary of the U.S. Treasury, itself has been a beneficiary of the improved climate; it came public in August at 21 a share and now trades for 37.60. The public's willingness to pay up for attractive issues lifts prices in the private market, as well.   Among last year's best tech IPOs were offerings for digital-storage companies Isilon Systems (ISLN) and ACME Packet (APKT), whose shares have more than doubled since, Roberts says. Riverbed Technology (RVBD), a data-services provider, has jumped more than 200% since its IPO, he notes.   Roberts has a good lay of the land. Before joining Evercore a year ago, he served five years as head of corporate development for Microsoft (MSFT), where he spearheaded the acquisition of Groove Networks. That deal brought in former Groove CEO Ray Ozzie, who has replaced Microsoft Chairman Bill Gates as the company's chief software architect.   Though the IPO market is improving for "quality companies," which he defines as those with more than $100 million in trailing 12-month revenues and high growth potential, Roberts expects corporate buyouts and other merger-and-acquisition activity to remain strong. "Private-equity firms are still trolling for tech," in particular information-security companies, he says.   Roberts declines to comment on the specifics of the Cisco (CSCO) deal because of his involvement. Few industry experts were surprised by the purchase, however, because of growing demand for information-security management. Most corporate customers of Cisco, the world's largest maker of networking gear, would prefer to buy security-management products from their primary network vendor rather than third parties.   The $2 billion messaging-security market is fragmented but growing by about 25% a year, says  Nikos Theodosopoulos, a UBS communications-gear analyst. IronPort caters to about 40% of the top 100 companies but only 20% of top 500. Cisco's sales force should be able to help it gain customers among the top 2,000 global companies, he says.   Cisco, which has an enviable reputation for integrating the companies it buys, studied IronPort as a partner for a few years before taking the plunge. In part, Cisco's success has been driven by its familiarity with its buyout targets, says Mike Irwin, chief operating officer of Webroot, a privately held maker of security software. "It's a good way for Cisco to enter the security market, using hardware as its entry point," says Irwin.   Should Cisco's foray into security worry incumbents like Symantec (SYMC) and McAfee (MFE)? The jury's out, but it can only help Cisco, whose shares rose 1.14 to 28.47 last week.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  January 06, 2007 00:06 ET (05:06 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Airlines Avoiding UK's Bristol Airport Due To Runway Woes
Story: LONDON (AP)--Nine airlines have decided not to fly into to Bristol International Airport because of concerns about the safety of its runway, officials said Saturday.   Nearly 100 flights will be diverted to other airports on Saturday, and 28 flights are to be canceled, the airport said in a statement. The nine airlines - easyJet, BA Connect, XL, Thomsonfly, Thomas Cook, Balkan Airlines, First Choice, Air Malta and SN Brussels - are worried about the reliability of the runway in wet conditions.   The airport's Web site said that other airlines, including Continental Airlines Inc. (CAL), KLM Group Ltd. (KLM.AU), and Ryanair Holdings Plc (RYAAY), are continuing to fly into Bristol, which is about 120 miles west of London.   Concerns about the runway began after the airport began resurfacing work in November.   "Over the past 24 hours we have been working with our airline partners to find an acceptable way forward," said Tony Hallwood, the airport's aviation development director. "We wish to reassure passengers that every effort is being made to ensure to that a normal service is resumed at Bristol International as soon as possible. The safety of our passengers is, as always, of paramount concern."     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  January 06, 2007 08:33 ET (13:33 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: : PTCH: Patch Announces Clarification of Acquisition of Damascus Energy Inc. and Completion of Private Placement
Story: (OTCBB: PTCH) (Frankfurt: PQGB)            VANCOUVER, Jan. 5 /PRNewswire-FirstCall/ -        Acquisition of Damascus Energy Inc.      -----------------------------------       Patch International Inc. ("Patch" or the "Corporation") (OTCBB: PTCH, Frankfurt: PQGB) is pleased to announce that it has completed the acquisition of all of the issued and outstanding securities of Damascus Energy Inc. ("Damascus"), a private corporation incorporated under the laws of Alberta (the "Transaction"), as previously announced in the press releases of Patch dated December 4, 2006 and December 21, 2006.     The acquisition was completed by way of exempt take-over bid, pursuant to a share exchange agreement between Patch, Patch Energy Inc. ("Patch Energy") (a wholly-owned subsidiary of Patch), Damascus and the holders of all of the issued and outstanding securities of Damascus (the "Share Exchange Agreement"), the holders of all of the issued and outstanding securities of Damascus exchanged their Damascus common shares for Series A Preferred Shares (the "Exchangeable Shares") of Patch Energy on a basis of one (1) Exchangeable Share for every two (2) Damascus common shares. Pursuant to the Transaction, 9,426,489 Exchangeable Shares were issued to the former securityholders of Damascus at a deemed value of (Cdn.) $1.00 per Exchangeable Share. Each Exchangeable Share is exchangeable, at the discretion of the holder, into one (1) common share of Patch. The number of Exchangeable Shares issued on the Transaction is less than the number previously intended to be issued as the private placement referenced below was completed directly into Patch rather than into Damascus.     Pursuant to an Exchange and Voting Trust Agreement entered into between Patch, Patch Energy and 1286664 Alberta Ltd. (the "Trustee"), the agreement stipulates the means by which (i) the holders of Exchangeable Shares will have voting rights in Patch; (ii) the Trustee will hold one (1) Class A Preferred Voting Share of Patch (the "Patch Preferred Share"); and (iii) the holders of Exchangeable Shares exercise their rights of conversion of the Exchangeable Shares, Patch issued one (1) Patch Preferred Share to the Trustee. The Patch Preferred Share has voting rights of 9,426,489 votes per Patch Preferred Share. The Trustee shall exercise the voting rights (and other rights attached to the Patch Preferred Share) for and on behalf of all of the holders of the Exchangeable Shares. Patch, Patch Energy and the Trustee also entered into a support agreement in respect of the Transaction.     Pursuant to the Transaction, the former officers and directors Patch and its subsidiaries resigned and Michael S. Vandale of Calgary, Alberta was appointed as a director of Patch and its subsidiaries. Michael S. Vandale was appointed President and Chief Executive Officer of Patch and Mr. Donald B. Edwards of Calgary, Alberta was appointed Corporate Secretary of Patch.     Patch is currently identifying individuals to act as additional directors of Patch and to fulfill the role of Chief Financial Officer of Patch.     It is the current intention of Patch to file a registration statement in the United Stated and to file a qualifying prospectus in Alberta, so that the Patch common shares issuable upon conversion of the Exchangeable Shares will be freely tradable in the future.        Private Placement     After completion of the Transaction, Patch completed a non-brokered financing (the "Financing") of 3,240,000 common shares, issued on a flow-through basis, ("Flow-Through Shares") at a subscription price of (Cdn.) $1.00 per share for gross proceeds of $3,240,000. In connection with the Financing Patch paid a finder's fee of 7% of the of the aggregate gross proceeds of the Financing to Canaccord Capital Corporation and Michael S. Vandale (the President and Chief Executive Officer and a director of Patch).     The net proceeds of the Financing will be used to fund development of the Damascus properties and incur and renounce qualifying expenditures to subscribers. The Flow-Through Shares issued pursuant to the Financing are subject to a hold period that expires four months and a day after the later of (i) the date the shares were issued, and (ii) the date that Patch becomes a reporting issuer in any province or territory of Canada. The Flow-Through Shares have not been registered under the United States Securities Act of 1933, as amended, or the securities laws of any state of the United States. The Flow-Through Shares may not be sold, transferred or assigned in the absence of an effective registration statement for the securities under the applicable securities laws, or unless offered, sold or transferred pursuant to an available exemption from the registration requirements of those laws. It is the current intention of Patch to file a registration statement in the United States and to file a qualifying prospectus in Alberta, so that the Flow-Through Shares will be freely tradable in the future        Please visit Patch's corporate website at www.patchenergy.com.     No regulatory authority has passed upon the merits of the proposed transaction and has not approved nor disapproved the contents of this press release.     This news release contains certain statements that may be deemed "forward-looking statements". All statements in this release, other than statements of historical fact, that address future production, reserve potential, exploration drilling, exploitation activities and events or developments that the Corporation expects to occur, are forward looking statements. Forward looking statements are statements that are not historical facts and are generally, but not always, identified by the words "expects", "plans" "anticipates", "believes", "intends", "estimates", "projects", "potential" and similar expressions, or that events or conditions "will", "would", "may", "could" or "should" occur. Information inferred from the interpretation of drilling results and information concerning mineral resource estimates may also be deemed to be forward looking statements, as it constitutes a prediction of what might be found to be present when and if a project is actually developed. Although the Corporation believes the expectations expressed in such forward-looking statements are based on reasonable assumptions, such statements are not guarantees of future performance and actual results may differ materially from those in the forward-looking statements. Factors that could cause the actual results to differ materially from those in forward-looking statements include market prices, exploitation and exploration successes, and continued availability of capital and financing, and general economic, market or business conditions. Investors are cautioned that any such statements are not guarantees of future performance and actual results or developments may differ materially from those projected in the forward-looking statements. Forward-looking statements are based on the beliefs, estimates and opinions of the Patch's management on the date the statements are made. The Corporation undertakes no obligation to update these forward-looking statements in the event that management's beliefs, estimates or opinions, or other factors, should change. For further information investors should review the Corporation's filings that are available at www.edgar.com.     CONTACT: Michael S. Vandale, Patch International Inc., President and Chief Executive Officer, 1-888-864-7372, email: mvandale@patchenergy.com.    SOURCE  Patch International Inc.       /CONTACT: Michael S.
