Headline: Barron's(1/8) Swimming In A Perilous Pool
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Leslie P. Norton   If the performance of Chinese stocks impressed you in 2006, you may have missed the story of a Nasdaq-listed company called Origin Agritech. Legally based in the British Virgin Islands but with operating headquarters in Beijing, Origin calls itself one of China's leading crop-seed companies. But while the Chinese market was jumping 100%-plus last year, Origin shares tumbled 14.5% to 10.94, for a recent market value of $250 million.   Blame the decline on fallout from the collapse of hedge fund Amaranth Advisors, which was not connected to Origin but owned a lot of companies like it -- special-purpose acquisition companies, or SPACs. These are blind pools that have been wildly successful at raising money from small investors to buy operating businesses ("The New Blind Pools," Dec. 12, 2005). According to a preliminary count by Petaluma, Calif.-based Reverse Merger Report, 37 SPACs came public last year, including five that raised $250 million to buy China businesses.   You can also blame the fall in Origin's shares to a series of blunders that might charitably be called growing pains. The company (ticker: SEED) filed its December 2005 annual report nearly four months late, announced a major change in revenue recognition, shifted to a September fiscal year and then fired its auditor. And it hardly endeared itself to shareholders when it held its annual meeting in Beijing, even though its stock trades only in the U.S.   Origin was the first China SPAC, raising $24 million as Chardan China Acquisition in March 2004 and buying the seed company in November '05, when it changed its name. It was led by Richard Propper, a physician and venture capitalist who had started an array of businesses, including Medibuy.com, a Website for marketing medical supplies. Propper subsequently launched two more bulletin-board-traded SPACs -- Chardan North China Acquisition (CNCA) and Chardan South China Acquisition (CSCA). He serves as chairman of the former and chief financial officer of the latter.   Propper is head of Chardan Capital, a San Diego-based venture capital firm. His son Kerry, who is an executive at both SPACs, heads the similarly named Chardan Capital Markets, a New York-based broker-dealer and investment bank.   The elder Propper has an eventful investment history. In the early '90s, he resigned as the managing general partner at Montgomery Medical Ventures, a venture-capital firm controlled by Montgomery Securities, amid reports that he inadvertently disclosed to a family member inside information about a Montgomery-related transaction. He now says only that the incident "had nothing to do with anything."   In 1996, meanwhile, he settled with the Securities and Exchange Commission over allegations that, as a general partner of two Montgomery funds, he failed to disclose holdings and transactions in several public companies. He says it was simply a matter of bookkeeping issues.   If this history has cast a shadow over Origin's shares, an early recovery is hardly likely in view of new litigation. On Dec. 29, the Justice Department filed a civil suit in federal court for the Eastern District of Pennsylvania against Propper, his partner Daniel Beharry, their former partner John Torkelsen and Sovereign Bancorp, alleging they'd defrauded the Small Business Administration of $32 million.     That suit is running parallel to a civil action filed by the SBA in early 2005. In that action, the government alleges the same plaintiffs funneled SBA money through Acorn Technology Fund, a small-business investment company, to their own companies. Among other things, it contends that Propper loaned money to Acorn to finance Medibuy, that Acorn repaid him with SBA money, and that Propper-related partnerships received more than $800,000 from Acorn. In June, Torkelsen began serving a 70-month prison sentence after pleading guilty to making false statements to the SBA.   A Justice Department spokesman says the government aims to recover up to $96 million from the defendants in its suit. In interviews last week, Propper and Beharry called the allegations in the suits "baseless." Sovereign says none of its current employees are involved.   Propper puts the whole blame on Torkelsen: "It was his doing completely. He's in jail. The SBA didn't oversee him as well as they could have, and they're just angry at the fact that money was lost." Torkelsen's attorney didn't return calls for comment.   As for Origin, Propper still does shareholder-relations work for the company. In an answer to e-mailed questions from Barron's, Origin's chief financial officer, Jeff Wang, declined to comment on the stock-price decline or the litigation, other than to state that Origin isn't named. Wang noted that Origin's revenues in the six months ended June 30 were $65 million and net income was $13 million, sharply higher than five years earlier, and that proprietary products now account for 10% and a growing portion of sales. And, he says, Origin remains focused on acquisitions.   Origin surely has its fans, including Maxim Group, which took the company public and claims it's worth $21 a share. Another is Propper: "Earnings are up significantly in 2006 and they'll be up significantly in 2007."   Propper remains "in love" with China and predicts that this year's market will sparkle "like 2006." But he has lost patience with SPACs. Will he form another one? "I don't think so. They take too long and they're too difficult to do."   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  January 06, 2007 00:08 ET (05:08 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(1/8) Quarterly Mutual Funds Review: Fund Firms: Picks Of The Pickers
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Lawrence C. Strauss   Interview with Cynthia Mayer and Guy Moszkowski   Research analysts, Merrill Lynch     Judging from their stocks' performances and price-earnings multiples, mutual-fund companies had a very good 2006, helped by strong inflows of cash from investors and solid equity-market gains. But can these stellar showings continue in 2007? For an informed opinion, we turned to Cynthia Mayer and Guy Moszkowski, veteran research analysts who track the industry for Merrill Lynch. To learn what they see ahead, read on.     Barron's: 2006 was a good year for many of the publicly traded asset-management firms. Many of these stocks outperformed the S&P 500, and their P/E multiples generally exceeded those of the market. How is 2007 looking for the group?   Mayer: It's always a great business with strong cash-flow generation. I don't think that will change. The valuations are close to peak, although not at the absolute peak. We expect to see some of the same themes, including globalization. Some of the asset managers that have more global footprints should continue to do well.     Q: What if the equity market, which has a big influence on these stocks, turns in a subpar performance this year?   Moszkowski: Broadly, that tends to favor some of the more fixed-income-driven firms. As for valuations, these companies trade at a significant premium to the market multiple, and deservedly so in many ways, because it is such a great business. That said, we have noted that market leadership has narrowed a lot this year.     Q: What impact does that have on the mutual-fund companies?   Moszkowski: It has become harder for active managers to beat their indexes. As of mid-December, about 30% of U.S. active equity funds were ahead of the S&P 500, compared with around 65% the year before. It's been in the 50% to 60% range. It's worrisome because what we've seen in the past, when active managers have trouble outperforming, is a higher percentage of assets flowing to alternatives like index products, exchange-traded funds and hedge funds. But it would probably be awhile before this phenomenon really showed up because it would have to persist long enough for the three- and five-year track records to really be affected. But if it did, we would expect the relative multiples for the mutual-fund group, on average, to decline.     Q: What's the profit growth picture for this year?   Mayer: Our average earnings-growth estimate is 16% for 2007, which is slightly down from the year-over-year earnings growth for 2006. But remember, too, asset managers' earnings are based on the amount they have under management, and they had a very strong fourth quarter. So they are actually set up pretty well for 2007. In terms of where they can [get] that growth, we still think that globalization is a big theme and that the growth will be faster in asset management outside the U.S. So the ones with greater access to those markets are growing faster.     Q: Such as?   Mayer: Franklin Resources [Ticker: BEN] is one, and AllianceBernstein [AB] is another.   Moszkowski: As always, the managers that produce very good numbers are going to do quite well. In a compressed market like the one we are talking about, since there will be fewer managers able to generate the meaningful outperformance, those guys might actually pick up market share, in terms of flows and of assets.   Mayer: Also, the Pension Reform Act has made it easier for companies to do automatic enrollment for 401(k) plans, and, once they've enrolled their employees, to put that money into more than just money-market funds. So that should benefit anybody who does a lot of 401(k) business, including T. Rowe Price Group [TROW].     Q: What's the situation for these companies in terms of margins?   Mayer: The operating margins are averaging around 35%. They came down a percent on average last year. They are still the best operating margins in financial services, and what we are seeing is growing scale for a lot of the businesses offsetting any pressure in fees. Also, there's been a migration toward higher-fee products like international funds and emerging-markets funds.     Q: What kind of a threat do alternative assets, including hedge funds, pose to these mutual-fund companies?   Mayer: It depends on each company. Some are seeing business taken away. In some areas, we're seeing institutional money migrate to hedge funds instead of traditional long-only managers. So there's definitely some loss of share there. At the same time, some of these companies are growing their alternatives business. Alliance is growing its alternatives business internally, and Legg Mason has a fund-of-funds manager, Permal Group. But one of the reasons asset managers have such a high multiple is because of their fees, which are so steady. So I think there are many who are interested in growing their alternatives business but also a little wary of shifting their business model to be more performance-fee dependent.     Q: Do exchange-traded funds, which have grown dramatically but whose assets are tiny compared with the fund industry's, pose a long-term threat?   Moszkowski: ETFs have been a passive product, partly because it's difficult to manage an active ETF. But if you look at the sum -- that is, the combination of exchange-traded funds and more traditional [index] products -- it is very clear that they are eating into the active-management base in mutual funds, just as they started to 20 years ago in the pension business. Last year, 36% of the net inflow into equity mutual funds was into passive funds, so it is meaningful.     Q: What do you see on the horizon for mergers and acquisitions in the industry?   Moszkowski: We have always thought that size and performance are at odds with each other. Therefore, to the extent that performance is an important ingredient in a money manager's success, certainly on the equity side, it would make you think twice about predicting a massive wave of consolidation. The industry is somewhat scaleable, but only to an extent, and very good economies of scale are available at sizes that are not enormous by the standards of the big companies. You don't need $1 trillion or $500 billion of assets under management in order to benefit from meaningful economies of scale. So I'm not sure that there is really the need for that much consolidation in the business.   Mayer: There might be consolidation among smaller companies that have a good track record and want to increase their distribution so they are incented to join up with someone with great distribution, because they feel that they've hit the wall in terms of how they can sell. Or the compliance costs are great enough so that they are spending too much time on compliance and not enough time on investment.     Q: Which asset managers look most attractive?   Moszkowski: We are most interested in stocks that seem pretty reasonably valued. A good cash cushion doesn't hurt, in case there is a downturn. And, as always, the ones that have better organic growth.     Q: Names, please.   Mayer: Again, AllianceBernstein and Franklin. We raised their price targets [last month]. They both reported very strong assets under management, and they are both beneficiaries of globalization in two ways. They both sell to non-U.S. clients, and they both manage a lot of assets in the global and international style. So that's an advantage, not only for faster growth in asset management outside the U.S., but also even within the U.S.   Investors are allocating a greater percentage of their money to non-U.S. and global assets. Franklin said recently that 40% of its gross sales are now from outside the U.S. So Alliance and Franklin have both trends working in their favor. For Franklin, a lot of their non-U.S. assets are not hedged. So to the extent the dollar declines, that helps them. And, of course, Franklin has something like $13 in net cash and investments per share. They haven't been specific but they will use some of it for share buybacks, dividends or acquisitions.     Q: What do you like about Nuveen Investments [JNC]?   Mayer: The company is very balanced, with 50% of its assets in equity funds. It also has a high proportion of its assets in closed-end funds, where there are no outflows, so it is very stable. It's also a good long-term play on the increasing number of people looking for more income-oriented investments. It's a very good cash-flow generator.     Q: Don't the price-earnings multiples on these companies look stretched to you?   Mayer: Not at all. We have Nuveen at 18.7 times 2007 earnings. The thing about Nuveen is that it has above-average organic growth, so it is one of the less expensive ways to access a high organic growth rate -- it was on track for 11% in 2006.   Moszkowski: It's definitely one of the industry leaders. Usually, the companies that have numbers like that have higher multiples. And a lot of the assets that Nuveen raises are in closed end-funds. We always refer to closed-ends as the Roach Motel of asset management, because the money comes in and never goes out. The assets will not be subject to outflows, and the manager will continue to manage them.   Mayer: Closed-end funds are a great business. On top of that, a lot of them are leveraged. This means that their manager can charge fees for the assets that are leveraged, as well as on the underlying base. Nuveen is also a leader in separately managed accounts, a business that is growing a little faster than mutual funds.     Q: Let's move on to Legg Mason [LM]. That firm's chief executive, Chip Mason, maintains that it's on target to integrate the former Citigroup assets into the firm. The stock, at around 97, is one of the group's laggards. What concerns you about Legg?   (MORE TO FOLLOW) Dow Jones Newswires  January 06, 2007 00:06 ET (05:06 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(1/8) 13D Filings
Story: (From BARRON'S)   13Ds are supposed to be filed within 10 days of an entity's attaining 5% or more of any class of a company's securities. Subsequent changes must be reported on amended filings. This material is from filings released by the SEC from  Dec. 28, 2006 to Jan. 3, 2007.   Source: Corporate Filings Alert     Activists     General Employment Enterprises (JOB)   Investor Daniel Zeff intends to nominate Andrew Dailey as a director for election at the next annual meeting. Dailey, a former analyst, executive and adviser to technology companies, is currently self-employed. Zeff holds 513,580 shares (10% of the total outstanding).     MAIR Holdings (MAIR)   Riley Investment Management, a major shareholder, sent a letter raising concerns about MAIR's proposed merger with Northwest Airlines. Northwest, under bankruptcy protection, is in talks to buy regional airline Mesaba Aviation, a unit of MAIR, which is also in bankruptcy. Riley said Northwest's  bid, valued at $145 million, is grossly inadequate. Riley urged that the interests of significant independent shareholders be represented in the talks. Riley owns 1,062,229 shares (5.2%).     Phoenix Technologies (PTEC)   A consortium including Ramius Capital Group and Starboard Value & Opportunity Master Fund sent a letter to the computer-software maker, nominating three candidates for election to the company's board of directors at the 2007 annual meeting. The Ramius/Starboard group said it intends to nominate John Mutch, Philip Moyer and Jeffrey Smith. The investors said they continue to believe the company's shares are undervalued, and that they're still interested in acquiring the company. Ramius and its affiliates own 3,502,941 shares (13.8%).     Openwave Systems (OPWV)   Harbinger Capital Partners Master Fund I filed a complaint in court against Openwave over the company's director nomination and annual meeting procedures. Harbinger filed a preliminary proxy on Dec. 28 to nominate two candidates for the communications and media software provider's board. The complaint  alleges that management has sought to thwart stockholders from nominating directors. Harbinger and its affiliates hold 10 million shares (10.6%).     Original Filings     M&F Worldwide (MFW)   Bay Harbour Management reported ownership of 1,041,200 shares (5.1%), after buying 88,700 shares from Nov. 9 to 27 at $15.40 each.     Increases in Holdings     Center Bancorp (CNBC)   Lawrence B. Seidman raised his stake to 1,203,640 shares (9.1%) by acquiring 182,888 shares from Nov. 29 to Dec. 26 at $15.66 to $15.80 a share.     MDS (MDZ)   ValueAct Partners boosted its stake to 17,705,600 shares (12.3%) by purchasing 650,000 from Nov. 2 to Dec. 22 at $17.17 to $18.42 apiece.   Decreases in Holdings     CKE Restaurants (CKR)   Pirate Capital cut its holdings to 5,048,034 shares (7.2%), unloading 2,000,000 on Dec. 28 at $18.53 a share.     Advo (AD)   UBS reduced its position to 2,264,095 shares (7.11%) by selling 334,600 from Dec. 6 to 27 at $29.00 to $32.99 each.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  January 06, 2007 00:05 ET (05:05 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Experts Debate Usefulness Of Creating Iraqi Jobs Program
Story: By Deb Riechmann   Of THE ASSOCIATED PRESS     WASHINGTON (AP)--Just as debate rages over sending more U.S. troops to Iraq, there are differing views about whether economic incentives such as micro-loans and U.S.-funded jobs programs would coax militiamen to trade guns for tools.   Some reconstruction experts say giving Iraqis jobs that include clearing streets and fixing water and sanitation systems would produce little economic benefit for a country on the brink of all-out civil war.   Others say civilian jobs programs - an idea President George W. Bush is considering - are designed to build security. Only when violence is under control, they say, can business flourish.   Details haven't been disclosed about the economic incentives Bush will announce as early as Wednesday. But those familiar with the plan say he is favoring short-term jobs programs, extending micro-loans to small business and increasing the amount of money that military commanders can spend quickly on local projects to improve the daily lives of Iraqis.   "Job creation is the most promising," said Michael O'Hanlon, a foreign policy analyst at the Brookings Institution. "I don't know why we haven't done it before. It's not the best way to build a new economy, but we need to address security even if that doesn't conform to Econ 101."   Military analysts say Army Lt. Gen. Peter Chiarelli, who recently finished his tour as the No. 2 general in Iraq, has recommended a short-term jobs program.   In a classified memo Donald H. Rumsfeld wrote two days before he resigned as defense secretary, he told the president: "Initiate a massive program for unemployed youth. It would have to be run by U.S. forces, since no other organization could do it."   Keith Crane, a senior economist at the RAND Corp., is skeptical because such programs employ insurgents but have little effect on their political activities. "In some instances, insurgents have participated in make-work schemes during the day, then fought the coalition at night," he says.   Bush also is considering allocating more money for a program established in 2003 to give field commanders money to solve local problems quickly - and show American compassion and good will. The program was allocated $753 million in the 2006 budget year.   The Iraq Study Group recommended that Bush find ways to give U.S. officials in Iraq the authority and flexibility to quickly fund projects that would help rebuild the nation.   Anthony Cordesman, an Iraq watcher at the Center for Strategic and International Studies, said the president is expected to propose a significant increase in discretionary funds available for the type of activities under the commanders' program. But he said the real question is how much and who would hand it out.   "The difficulty you have with almost everything that comes out of the Bush administration is that there's a concept, but there's never a plan and there's almost never any real details in it," he said.   Crane, an adviser to the Iraq Study Group, said it is unclear how effective this money is in countering the insurgency or fostering conditions for economic growth and permanent employment.   He said funds in the military commanders' program are best used in moderation because commanders are not specialists in development projects.   "In some cases, the commanders have been manipulated by the local sheiks, in essence ripped off," he said.   On the positive side, he said, commanders often have a good idea, after talking with Iraqis, about what is most needed - or even what would help soothe their devastation and loss.   "A lot of the money has been used by commanders to compensate people whose homes have been destroyed," Crane said. "Commanders have ended up paying Iraqis for pets that have been killed as well."   In Najaf, one coalition commander shelled out $100 for the death of a dog, he said.   As Bush prepares to detail his economic incentives, the Pentagon is moving ahead with a program to help reopen factories that were owned by Saddam Hussein's government and abandoned after the U.S.-led invasion in March 2003.   Defense officials have declined to identify the facilities for fear the factories, or their employees, could be attacked.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  January 06, 2007 13:02 ET (18:02 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: US Experts To Help Probe Apparent Crash Of Indonesian Jet
Story: MAKASSAR, Indonesia (AP)--U.S. experts arrived on Indonesia's Sulawesi island Saturday to help investigate the apparent crash of a jetliner that disappeared with 102 people on board after battling fierce winds and storms.   The pilot did not issue a mayday before dropping off the radar near the coastal town of Majene, and there has been no emergency location signal to guide thousands of rescuers fanning out across the island's dense jungles and surrounding seas.   By nightfall Saturday, after a fifth day of searching, there was still no trace of the Boeing 737 of Indonesian budget carrier Adam Air.   "It's impossible that it just disappeared," Indonesia's Vice President Jusuf Kalla said after meeting with search officials and families of the passengers of Flight KI-574. He promised to spare no efforts in finding out what happened.   "Even if it takes a month...we have to keep searching," Kalla said.   Patrick Smith, a U.S.-based airline pilot and aviation commentator, said "whatever happened to the plane, it was likely rapid and catastrophic," pointing to a possible massive structural failure due to metal fatigue, or an onboard explosion.   He noted that in many accidents, "there are no distress calls simply because the cockpit crew is too busy dealing with the situation rather than calling around for help."   The plane left Indonesia's main island of Java for Manado on Sulawesi on Monday afternoon. It altered course and turned westward halfway into the two-hour trip after being warned of rough weather near the city of Makassar, said Eddy Suyanto, head of the search and rescue mission.   When it ran into winds of more than 130 kph over the Makassar Strait, it changed course again, bringing the plane eastward toward land, then lost contact, he said.   Kalla said finding the plane has now become an "international issue" because of the length of time the plane has been missing.   Singapore has already joined the search, and a U.S. National Transportation Safety Board team arrived on Sulawesi to help investigate the possible crash of the American-made plane, which was carrying a man from the U.S. state of Oregon and his two daughters.   The six-member team - which included representatives from Boeing Co. (BA), General Electric Co. (GE) and the Federal United States' Aviation Administration - made no comment upon arriving in Makassar. U.S. embassy officials said they would provide Indonesia with whatever help they could in the investigation.   It isn't clear why there were never any transmissions from the plane's emergency locator.   Smith speculated it may not have been working, or - in the event of a crash at sea - that it could have sunk into an underwater trench from which its signals could not be picked up.   Saturday's aerial search focused on land and waters along 500 kilometers of coastline from Palu city in the north to Makassar in the south, said Suyanto.   Three warships will also comb the Makassar Strait area, said Suparman, chief of Makassar Search and Rescue Agency. Like many Indonesians, Suparman uses a single name.   Authorities had wrongly said Tuesday that the wreckage had been found with a dozen survivors, causing further anguish to relatives camped out at airports and hotels in Manado and Makassar.   Many family members have provided the disaster crisis center with medical records, photographs and other information that would be needed to help identify the dead.   "All we do is watch television," said Fandi, who had four relatives on the plane. "Officials from Adam Air aren't able to tell us anything."   Adam Air is one of about 30 budget carriers that sprang up in Indonesia after 1998, when the industry was deregulated. The rapid expansion has led to cheap flights to scores of destinations across Indonesia, but has also raised concerns about maintenance of the leased planes.   Air navigation can be difficult in Indonesia, which spans 6% of the equator, due to gaps in communications systems. Last year, an Adam Air Boeing 737 flew off course along the same route and was lost for several hours before it made an emergency landing at a small airstrip, hundreds of kilometers off course.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  January 06, 2007 08:55 ET (13:55 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(1/8) European Trader: A Buying Opportunity For Anglo American
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Martin Fluck and Arindam Nag   Anglo American is one of the most attractive mining stocks, but its shareholders won't soon make any money on it. Indeed, one of its biggest virtues is that they stand to lose only a quarter of the value of their investment now that the base-metals bubble seems to be bursting. Investors in some rivals could lose more.   Anglo, whose American depositary shares trade on Nasdaq under the ticker symbol AAUK, is turning itself into a focused mining company from the conglomerate it was in 1999, disposing of $10 billion in non-core assets and making $15 billion in acquisitions. But Anglo still retains paper and packaging and industrial-minerals operations.   These businesses have left it less exposed than some of its peers to base metals, which accounted for only 16% of Anglo American's revenue, compared with 58% at Xstrata (XTA.London) and 43% at Rio Tinto (RTP). This is good news now that large and formerly hidden inventories of metal could send copper below its long-run trend under $2,300 a ton from its recent level above $6,000.   Even zinc, which spiked on shrinking London Metal Exchange stocks last fall, looks vulnerable now that Chinese producers -- like those elsewhere -- are ramping up output to take advantage of high prices. China, whose net zinc exports in November hit their highest level since May 2002, has enough spare zinc smelting capacity to remain a significant net exporter in 2007.   If base-metals prices come back to earth, Anglo American's operating profit would fall 25% or so -- as $2.5 billion of its forecast $10 billion operating profit in 2006 reflects a windfall from the spike in copper prices. But Xstrata's operating profit would slip by 50%, and Rio Tinto's by 40%.   Where does this leave Anglo's incoming CEO, Cynthia Carroll, who will be the first woman in charge of a large mining company? There may be less pressure on her to accelerate the restructuring announced in Anglo's 2005 strategic review. That plan called for the company to cut its gold-mining interests and to spin off its paper and packaging business. Absent these moves, some investors think the company risks a takeover bid from the likes of Rio Tinto or Xstrata.   What Carroll could do, however, is return less cash to shareholders, with a view to buying one of its more volatile competitors. In 2006, Anglo American returned $7.5 billion -- maybe enough to buy Xstrata -- through dividends and stock buybacks. As outgoing CEO Tony Trahar says, Anglo American likes to buy when prices are low.     The acquisition of a 5% stake in Cobham by a member of Spain's steel-making Vilaseca family is unlikely to trigger a bid for the U.K. defense and aerospace outfit. Cobham would probably cost more than 2.5 billion British pounds ($4.85 billion), likely beyond the Vilasecas' means.   But the Vilasecas could shake up a segment of the U.K.'s defense sector that needs to be shaken up, whether it's by pressuring management to make acquisitions or to return more cash to shareholders.   Cobham is guilty of doing neither.   Cobham's stock (COB.London) trailed the FTSE All-Share index for most of the past year until hope emerged that it would do a value-enhancing acquisition, probably in the U.S. But no deal has materialized, even though Cobham has net debt of less than GBP 100 million, and specializes in areas where barriers to entry are relatively high, such as air-to-air refueling, antenna and microwave systems.   The company achieved 8.6% growth in last year's first half, indicating that its restructuring, in which it has sold a clutch of low-quality businesses, is paying off. But its underleveraged balance sheet frustrates investors. The Vilasecas probably will pressure Cobham to buy a rival or pay a special dividend. U.K. takeover candidates include Meggitt (MGGT.London) and Melrose (MRO.London), where earnings growth is slack and stock performance weak.   ---   Martin Fluck and Arindam Nag are contributors to The Skeptic, a column on which this European Trader is based.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  January 06, 2007 00:07 ET (05:07 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(1/8) Follow-Up: Nucor: A Steal At Recent Discount?
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Jim McTague   Pearl Harbor Day 2006 included its own bit of drama for steel maker Nucor's shares. Bears started attacking the stock price that morning, sending it down from a 52-week high of $67.55 to under $55 a share in the next week or so. Weaker steel prices, rising inventories, the end of an import tariff and analyst downgrades all contributed to the slide. Shortly thereafter, Nucor said its fourth-quarter earnings would be strong but below record levels, further undermining the stock.   In light of a probable soft economic landing this year and the shares' stellar performance until early December, the bears might want to take cover. "I view this as an opportunity for investors," says Mark Parr, a steel analyst for Keybanc Capital Markets in Cleveland.   Parr sees Nucor (ticker: NUE) hitting $70 this year as worldwide demand for steel outpaces global GDP growth. The removal of tariffs should be offset by the tumble in the U.S. dollar, which makes foreign steel more expensive here, he says.   It's certainly hard to find fault with the shares' resilience. Barron's 16 months ago correctly predicted a post-Katrina boost for Nucor ("The Long Road Ahead" Sept. 5, 2005) after the federal government pledged billions of dollars to rebuild ravaged highways and bridges. Nucor was trading at $29 then on a split-adjusted basis. Even at its reduced level, the stock has nearly doubled since; at its top the gain was 133%.   Nucor is expected to report earnings of $5.38 to $5.48 a share for 2006, versus $4.13 in 2005. Parr looks for earnings to hit $6 this year. The shares now trade at a multiple of four times enterprise value (equity value, plus debt, less cash) divided by his 2007 expectations for earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization, below their historical norm of five to eight times.   Not everyone is so enthused. Timna Tanners, a steel analyst at UBS, agrees that the stock is oversold, but her target for Nucor is a more modest $60. "You can buy on dips because it's a solid company with good management, a decent growth story and a strong history," she says. More federal spending on highways and bridges in 2007 will also help.   But she's neutral for the long haul because Nucor's a bigger, less nimble company than previously, with lesser growth prospects. The $1.07 billion price Nucor offered last week for Canadian processor Harris Steel was not cheap, she adds, a sign "they are running out of easy things to pick off."   Tanners prefers Steel Dynamics (STLD), a smaller, more entrepreneurial company with a cheaper valuation.   Still, Nucor shares do seem to offer value right now even if they require more investor mettle for the metal in 2007 than they did just after Katrina hit.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  January 06, 2007 00:08 ET (05:08 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: US Judge Adds $3.3M To Ford Verdict In Okla Accident Case
Story: TULSA, Okla. (AP)--A federal judge added more than $3.3 million in interest to a $15 million verdict a jury awarded to a Tulsa couple whose son was killed in a 2003 traffic accident.   U.S. Chief District Judge Claire Eagan decided $3,339,550.68 in prejudgment interest from Ford Motor Co. (F) should be added to the amount the jury awarded Kevin and Veronica Moody on Nov. 20.   Moody attorney Clark Brewster said Friday evening that prejudgment interest is called for under Oklahoma law.   Prejudgment interest compensates a plaintiff for the loss of the use of compensatory damages from the time the lawsuit was filed until the date of judgment.   Under Oklahoma law, courts do not have the power to deny or reduce prejudgment interest, according to Eagan's order.   Tulsa jeweler Kevin Moody and Veronica Moody filed the lawsuit Nov. 18, 2003, a little more than 10 months after their 18-year-old son, Tyler Moody, was killed in a single-vehicle rollover crash.   Moody lost control of the 1995 Ford Explorer Sport while he was passing another vehicle in a no-passing zone on a curve, according to a Nov. 14 order entered by Eagan.   The speeding SUV left the road and rolled at least 1 1/2 times, coming to rest on its roof.   In their lawsuit, the Moodys alleged that "because the defective vehicle had an inadequate roof-crush tolerance," Tyler Moody was trapped in the Explorer "and his neck was pushed into his chest by the intruding roof at a precipitous angle."   Testimony showed that Moody was wearing his seat belt and sustained no obvious physical injury beyond a five-inch bruise on the top of his head in the Jan. 16, 2003, crash.   However, his airway was blocked to such an extent that he died of "positional asphyxiation," according to the lawsuit.   But Ford attorney Mary Quinn Cooper said the vehicle exceeded federal standards. She said 98% of seat-belted SUV riders who are in rollover accidents sustain no serious injuries.   Cooper said that while there was no doubt that Moody was "a great kid," on the day of the accident he made "bad decisions that had fatal consequences."     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  January 06, 2007 09:20 ET (14:20 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: State Bk Of India Revises Local Term Deposit Interest Rate
Story: MUMBAI (Dow Jones)--State Bank of India (500112.BY), the country's largest bank by assets, said Saturday it has decided to revise the interest rate on domestic term deposits of at least 1.50 million rupee but less than INR10 million ($225,819) to 8.25% per annum for all maturities of one year and longer.   In a news release, the bank said the offer will be effective from Monday and will expire March 31.   No other details were provided in the news release.     -By Mumbai Bureau; Dow Jones Newswires; 91-9900181471; djn.in@dowjones.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  January 06, 2007 03:45 ET (08:45 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Nikko Cordial Seeks Fincl Help From Mizuho Corp Bk-Kyodo
Story: NEW YORK (Dow Jones)--Nikko Cordial Corp. (8603.TO), reeling from accounting irregularities, has asked Mizuho Corporate Bank and other financial institutions to help it with short-term funding, Kyodo news reported Saturday, citing sources familiar with the matter.   Nikko Cordial executives are also apparently considering asking the bank and other major shareholders to slightly raise their stakes in the country's third-largest securities firm, the sources said, according to Kyodo.    A new Nikko Cordial management team, set up in late December, has approached financial institutions the company deals with and asked whether they can assist it financially in an attempt to restore customer trust, the sources said, Kyodo reported.   Nikko Cordial and Mizuho Corporate Bank struck a capital alliance deal in December 2004. The bank under the wing of Mizuho Financial Group Inc. held a 4.82% stake in the brokerage group as of March 2006, the report said.   In December, Nikko Cordial admitted to the falsification of fiscal 2004 earnings, the report said.   Since then, the brokerage, which also has a capital tie-up with Citigroup Inc. (C) of the U.S., has been losing customers, Kyodo reported.   On Friday, the Financial Services Agency slapped a fine of JPY500 million on Nikko Cordial for padding its profits, the report said.   The penalty, which was recommended by the Securities and Exchange Surveillance Commission late last year, is the largest ever imposed by the country's financial watchdog, the report said.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  January 06, 2007 06:42 ET (11:42 GMT)

Headline: Three Banks In Athens Damaged By Suspected Anarchists
Story: ATHENS (AP)--Suspected anarchists armed with firebombs and rocks damaged three banks in the Greek capital on Saturday, authorities said.   Police said some 30 anarchists attacked three Athens banks on central Mitropoleos street shortly after midnight Friday. The hooded youths torched a Bank of Cyprus (BOC.CP) ATM machine and smashed the windows of Emporiki Bank of Greece (TEMP.AT) and Eurobank, police said.   No arrests or injuries were reported.   Athens police have had near nightly clashes with anarchist groups since the arrest of demonstrators several months ago during violent street protests against education reforms.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  January 06, 2007 11:38 ET (16:38 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: UK PRESS:Vodafone Vows Not To Overpay In Bid For Hutchison
Story: LONDON (Dow Jones)--Vodafone Group Plc (VOD) is seeking to fend off concerns about its involvement in the $20 billion bid battle for Hutchison Esssar, India's fourth-biggest mobile player, insisting that it won't overpay, The Times reported Saturday, citing a Vodafone spokesman.   The mobile operator has vowed not to breach the strict financial criteria recently introduced by Arun Sarin, its chief executive, in hopes of reassuring investors, the paper said.   Newspaper Web site: http://www.timesonline.co.uk   -London Bureau, Dow Jones Newswires; +44 (0)20 7842 9320     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  January 06, 2007 06:16 ET (11:16 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: : Riley Investment Management LLC Opposes Current Northwest Proposal for Mesaba Airlines, a Subsidiary of MAIR Holdings, Inc.
Story: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 6 /PRNewswire/ -- Riley Investment Management LLC released the following statement opposing Northwest Airlines' proposal for Mesaba Airlines, a subsidiary of MAIR Holdings, Inc. (Nasdaq: MAIR):     As a large shareholder of MAIR Holdings, Inc., the owner of Mesaba Airlines, Riley Investment Management LLC continues to believe that Northwest Airlines' proposed offer to acquire Mesaba Airlines in exchange for the allowance of Mesaba $145 million claim against Northwest is grossly inadequate considering we value the total value of the Mesaba estate to be in excess of $300 million (Mesaba's original claim amount plus +$100 million value of Mesaba's SAAB business).  We will pursue all avenues to ensure that such a transaction is not consummated.  Our contemplated actions may include any or all of the following:  filing objections to the creditors' current motion requesting the termination of exclusivity period for filing a plan of reorganization, pursuing litigation against various parties to the transaction, offering our own competing plan of reorganization if exclusivity is terminated, or entering into discussion with MAIR Holdings or other regional carriers.  Additionally, we have been in discussions with numerous other large shareholders who share our concerns and support our actions. Additionally, we would like to note that contrary to what has been stated in the press, Mesaba Airlines has not agreed to any terms of the Northwest agreement.  We believe this would require board approval at Mesaba as well as board approval at MAIR, neither of which has occurred.     We believe that Northwest Airlines has destroyed value for MAIR shareholders, Mesaba and Mesaba's employees, enabling Northwest to buy Mesaba below fair market value and avoid fairly paying Mesaba's valid claims in the Northwest bankruptcy.  MAIR and Mesaba management have been unfairly criticized by its unions and the press for actions we believe were forced by Northwest.  Northwest's bankruptcy filing and request for new RFPs for additional flying forced Mesaba to subject its employees to new labor contracts so that Mesaba could make attractive proposals to Northwest to continue to fly aircraft.  Northwest is now attempting to purchase Mesaba and use this low cost structure as a vehicle to continue and buildup Northwest's regional business with all future value only going to Northwest Airlines. Below is a timeline of events related to the Mesaba bankruptcy and Northwest Airlines.          *  Prior to Mesaba bankruptcy filing: Mesaba operates a fleet of         63 SAAB-340 and 35 Avro-Regional Jet aircraft for NWA.  Trailing twelve         month revenue at Mesaba through 9/30/2005 was $416MM.        *  August 29, 2005:  Northwest signs a new ASA with Mesaba in which MAIR         is required to invest $31.7 million into Mesaba.  Under the terms,         Mesaba would operate 35 AVRO and up to 15 CRJ-200/440 aircraft along         with all of the existing 63 SAAB aircraft under a 10-year contract.        *  September 9, 2005: Bryan Ebensteiner, NWA Director of Airlink Planning,         sends an email to MAIR inquiring whether MAIR had made the required         $31.7 payment to Mesaba; Mesaba advises NWA that it had made the         payment.        *  September 12, 2005: After it is ensured that liquidity had been         provided to Mesaba from MAIR, Northwest fails to make its regular         semi-monthly payment to Mesaba of $18.5 million for the second half of         August.        *  September 14, 2005:  Northwest files for bankruptcy.  We find it hard         to imagine that Northwest management did not know that it was         contemplating filing for bankruptcy two weeks prior when it signed a         new ASA with Mesaba.  Shares of MAIR drop from $9.50/share to         $4.50/share costing MAIR shareholders $100 million in value.  A few         days after Northwest files for bankruptcy, Doug Steenland, CEO of         Northwest, resigned from the board of directors of MAIR.        *  September 26, 2005: Northwest failed to make the full semi-annual         payment to Mesaba for the first half of September, reducing the payment         to $1.9 million.  Total missed payments are approximately         $36.4 million.        *  August 16, 2006: Mesaba files a $250 million claim against Northwest         Airlines which does not include the value of its current SAAB business         which we value at an additional +$100 million (our analysis is set         forth below).        *  November 27, 2006:  After Northwest's bankruptcy filing, Mesaba was         forced to seek labor concession with its unions in order to continue         operations and ensure continued and future business with Northwest.         Labor currently has a $22.7 million claim against Mesaba for contract         concession.        *  December 20, 2006:  Northwest offers Mesaba a $145 million claim in         total to purchase the entire company.  In all we value the offer at 63%         of the value of Mesaba prior to filing for bankruptcy, which ignores         incremental value which would have accrued to Mesaba since under the         new ASA, where it had rights to operate the next 35 CRJ aircraft in         Northwest's regional fleet.        *  December 22, 2006: Northwest settles with Pinnacle Airlines for a         $377.5 million claim and awards Pinnacle a new ASA that allows it to         continue flying for Northwest as a standalone public entity.  Terms of         the new ASA allow Pinnacle to continue to operate all of its existing         124 CRJ-200/440 aircraft plus up to an additional 17 CRJ-200/440         aircraft for 10 years.  15 of these CRJ's were originally promised to         Mesaba when they signed their ASA.  In all we estimate the value         Pinnacle's award to be worth $530 million, which is approximately 135%         of the estimated value of its prior contract (our analysis is set forth         below).       In light of the items mentioned above, we believe that not only is Northwest Airlines not offering fair value for Mesaba, it also pursued a strategy of destroying value in order to purchase Mesaba's at a huge discount to its fair value.  At best, Northwest and its executives ignored clear conflict of interest issues (Northwest owns 28% of MAIR and a director of Northwest also sat on MAIR's board) and at worst, fraud occurred.  Under the proposed transaction, Northwest stands to reap the entire economic benefit of Mesaba's labor concessions with cheaper flying costs for Northwest going forward, but only after Mesaba and therefore MAIR shareholders pay for the $22.7 million claim owed to Mesaba's labor unions.  To be clear, we are not opposed to Northwest acquiring Mesaba, as we believe all parties including employees, creditors, customers and shareholders can be made whole under appropriate terms.  But we are strongly opposed to the offer of $145 million. In light of this, we will continue to pursue any and all strategies that will maximize value for shareholders of MAIR.
