Headline: Barron's(1/8) Quarterly Mutual Funds Review: Living Large, In A Fishbowl
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Lawrence C. Strauss   At the end of 2001, the American Funds had about $340 billion under management, well behind behemoths Fidelity and Vanguard. Toward the end of last year, however, after a phenomenal growth spurt, the total had almost tripled, to $959 billion, according to Financial Research Corp. in Boston. Such is the power of investment success and a glowing reputation among investors.   Today, privately held American Funds is the largest U.S. mutual-fund complex when measured by long-term assets, which exclude money funds. Fidelity, which ranks third, is still the largest U.S. fund complex, with $1.1 trillion under management, when money funds are taken into account. Vanguard is second, with just under $1.1 trillion, while American comes in a close third, with $972 billion.   Regardless of how you slice it, American Funds has become a juggernaut, each month attracting billions of dollars of fresh cash to its broker-sold funds and its big 401(k) business. The company's 30 mutual funds, whose adviser is Los Angeles-based Capital Research and Management, were helped by a relatively strong showing during the market downturn earlier this decade. And when the market-timing and late-trading scandals pummeled the mutual-fund industry three years ago, Capital got another boost. It, unlike many of its rivals, came through the mess with an unsullied reputation. That enhanced its popularity with the people who sell its funds. "Brokers just don't want to get burned by another fund company," says Paul Herbert, an analyst at Morningstar, the Chicago-based fund-tracking and investment-research outfit.   American Funds hasn't entirely escaped the regulatory glare. The National Association of Securities Dealers, the Securities and Exchange Commission and the California attorney general's office are looking into alleged improprieties involving the compensation of certain broker-dealers who peddle American Funds. The firm has denied any wrongdoing. These regulatory dustups haven't hurt the firm's reputation, judging from the inflows. "What makes them so extraordinary is that they do what everyone says you're supposed to do, which is fundamental research and long-term investing," says Harold Evensky, a financial planner in Coral Gables, Fla.     But are some of the funds getting too big? Maybe. But even if they are, Capital Research appears flexible enough to do whatever is needed to ensure that performance remains healthy.   There's no doubt that the issue concerns some investors and financial advisers. "That is a heck of a lot of money," says John Casey, chairman of Casey, Quirk & Associates, an asset-management consultancy in Darien, Conn. "I think they're going to be able to handle it for a while, but they may have to close some of these funds."   Indeed, the company's largest fund, Growth Fund of America (ticker: AGTHX), has ballooned to more than $160 billion, a sum bigger than the total assets of most entire fund firms. Of the 12 largest funds tracked by Lipper, seven are in the American stable. Nine of its 30 funds have assets exceeding $50 billion.   "They are in uncharted waters," adds Casey. "On an actively managed basis, nobody has ever been there."   For an individual fund or an entire complex, size can be the enemy. That's partly because as more money flows in, the manager is forced to take larger positions in individual stocks, thereby making it harder to trade in and out of those holdings, especially during crises. It also constrains the manager's choice of securities.   Executives at Capital Research, while acknowledging that size poses a challenge and that they analyze its impact on performance constantly, insist that their system is working fine.   "The actual asset size hasn't affected us much," maintains Timothy Armour, president of Capital Research and a portfolio counselor for four of the funds. "Our system is able to accommodate it very effectively."   That system dates to the Great Depression and has succeeded through dozens of market cycles since then. Launched in 1931 by Jonathan Bell Lovelace, a World War I veteran with a head for numbers and a flair for stock research, American Funds has quietly grown into a colossus. From the outset, the firm has emphasized buying securities at reasonable prices, taking a long-term view (with low turnover, relative to other fund firms) and carrying out top-notch research to provide an edge in security selection.     Shunning publicity, American Funds rarely grants interview requests, although it did agree to speak with Barron's for this story. And, rather amazingly in this age of 24-hour-a-day hype, it doesn't advertise in mainstream publications. Many of its employees joined its staff directly from college or business school. They learn the Capital way of doing business, and often stay for a long time.   The firm's culture "hasn't changed," says Paul G. Haaga Jr., vice chairman of Capital Research. "It's about investing money the right, long-term way and not getting into fads."   There is no star system at American, whose funds are team-managed. That contrasts with the situation at, say, Legg Mason or Fidelity, whose funds, in part, often fall or rise in popularity on the reputations of well-known individual managers like Bill Miller or Peter Lynch.   "You hear so much about shops where the marketing forces trump the investing forces," says Morningstar's Herbert. "Here, I really think the investing forces have a huge say in how things are done."   That's evidenced in part by avoiding the fund du jour mentality -- introducing funds to fill niches that were all the rage at the moment -- that overtook some other complexes, particularly in the late 1990s. And, also unlike some firms, where research analysts jockey to become portfolio managers, Capital offers a career research track with a twist: Analysts can run money, often 20% to 25% of the assets in a particular fund.   For fund managers and analysts, compensation hinges on, among other factors, four-year rolling returns against a benchmark.   In an unusual approach, American Funds uses a "multi-portfolio counselor" system, in which individual managers run their own "sleeve" of a fund -- a certain percentage of its assets. Each sleeve is run autonomously. This gives each counselor leeway to pursue the ideas about which he or she holds the strongest convictions. In theory, this system, which Capital Research first employed in the late 1950s, creates a portfolio that is more diverse than it would be if one manager were making the selections. The approach also reduces the overlap in holdings and trades.   Despite the American Funds' sterling track record, Morningstar's Herbert fears that the group's growing girth is "putting additional strain on people and processes and ultimately performance." To help manage the growth, Capital is boosting its staff of investment analysts and counselors by about 8% annually. Currently, it has about 150 worldwide.   Herbert says he's "yet to see a cause- and-effect relationship" between the size of funds and their performance, though he cautions that investors should be aware of how large some of these funds are. And he's concerned about how well the firm will manage its growth.   A West Coast fund manager calls the amazing asset growth "a little bit of a question mark" and warns that "you can have all the research you want, but it's just too big." But this manager adds: "They have good managers and good people who will be smart enough to make a change if they need to make a change."   Comments CR president Armour: "If we ever got to the point where we felt the size of a fund would limit our ability to generate superior long-term returns, we would do something." Presumably, that would mean closing one or more funds.   There are benefits -- as well as dangers -- in being the big kid on the block, of course. "Their performance has held up very well, despite their size," says a broker at a major firm who puts clients' money into some American funds. "At the end of the day, they demonstrate solid risk-adjusted performance with modest expenses, one of the benefits of being big and which they pass on to investors."   In fact, scale has helped the funds' hold down their expense ratios, which Morningstar says are among the industry's lowest.     For those who fret about the company's swelling asset base, the $160 billion Growth Fund of America, the largest fund in the country, isn't good fodder for criticism. Its three-year annual return of 12.32%, which beats the S&P 500's by nearly two percentage points, ranks in the top 5% of Morningstar's large-cap growth category, as do its five- and 10-year returns. The fund, which has benefited from an overweighting in energy and a big position in Google (GOOG), holds more than 300 stocks, according to its most recent annual report. Responsibility for them is divvied up among 10 portfolio managers.   To better manage the huge cash inflows, Capital Research has broken its equity-management team into two groups: Capital World Investors and Capital Research Global Investors. There's also a bond team. "You are in a much better learning environment when you are working with 15 or 20 people instead of 80 or 90," says Armour.   The fund shop has come in for some criticism from those who maintain that the funds' holdings overlap too much. For example, 60% of the securities in the Washington Mutual Investors (AWSHX) and American Mutual (AMRMX) funds overlap, a result that Capital Research says is a result of their having similar investment objectives, notably a focus on dividend-paying stocks. Another cause of overlap: Because of their size, several American Funds must concentrate on the most liquid segment of the stock market, large-cap issues.     "We can get overlap, no question," says Armour. "But we don't try to stop that. We feel pretty strongly that the investment process is a very fragile one. If you try to direct from up above one's ability to buy and sell securities at one time, that inhibits the process and will result in negative outcomes."   (MORE TO FOLLOW) Dow Jones Newswires  January 06, 2007 00:07 ET (05:07 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(1/8) Cleaning Up On Tyco's Breakup
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Jonathan R. Laing   These days, analysts and money managers often roll their eyes at the mere mention of Tyco International. Many were badly burned when the stock collapsed from a high around 60 in late 2001 to below 7 in July of the following year, after revelations that Dennis Kozlowski, then chairman and CEO, and Mark Swartz, then-chief financial officer, had looted some $170 million from the company. The two are now doing hard time in state prison, following convictions in New York StateSupreme Court in 2005.   Then the deep-value crowd clambered aboard Tyco, betting that new CEO Ed Breen would right the ship and transform the company into the smoothly operating growth engine that the Kozlowski regime promised but delivered only by deceptive accounting. Breen did manage to cut costs and lift the company out of a potentially lethal liquidity squeeze. But lackluster profit growth over the past two years has caused the stock to largely flat-line, bobbing in a range of roughly 25 to 35. Tyco now changes hands at 30.40.   Nor has the plan to split the unwieldy conglomerate into three units in this year's first quarter -- through spinoffs to shareholders of its health-care business, electronics unit, and fire-and-security and engineered-products-and-services operations -- created much buzz. For one thing, the split-up is stale news, having been announced in January of last year.   Fairly typical of Wall Street opinion on Tyco is that of JPMorgan analyst C. Stephen Tusa, who explains his Neutral rating thus: "This is a company with a history of constant restructuring charges, asset write-downs and unfavorable developments. We're also perhaps late in the global growth cycle, which the company has some exposure to. Perhaps the most favorable thing one can say about Tyco is that most everybody is pessimistic about the company."   Likewise, longtime multi-industry analyst Nicholas Heymann of Prudential worries in a recent report that following the spinoffs, the profit growth of the units (especially the health-care unit) will be hurt by the necessity of a sharp boost in research and development spending. This, he contends, is largely a result of a decade of underinvestment, both during the years of the Kozlowski magic show and under Breen. Heymann sees the stock headed to 26 within 12 months.   Yet in the face of this negativity, the T. Rowe Price Capital Appreciation Fund (PRWCX) has been building a substantial position in Tyco in the past six months in anticipation of the spinoffs. This wouldn't be the fund's first foray into Tyco. It was among the many investors hurt during the Kozlowski meltdown -- but it could well be onto something this time.   Co-manager Jeff Arricale says Tyco is one of the fund's "most compelling" ideas when one considers the values at which he expects the three new companies will trade at over the next several years. Tyco currently trades at about 15 times consensus estimates of $2.02 a share for its fiscal year ending Sept. 30, 2007 and 13.5 times consensus forecasts for fiscal 2008 of $2.25 a share. The price-earnings ratios of pure plays in the industries Tyco is moving into are indeed higher.   Though it's still too early to say which of the spinoffs may fare the best, the three as a group could reward investors nicely. In fiscal 2006, Tyco earned $3.7 billion, or $1.80 a share, fully diluted, on revenues of $41 billion. Based on fiscal 2008 projections of earnings for the three surviving companies, Arricale sees them trading at a combined value of $38 to $45 a share.   "We think that the price of Tyco has been unnaturally depressed because of investor battle fatigue and the fact that the industrial analysts who cover the company have lost interest in the company with the spin-outs coming and a handoff of coverage to other analysts in the offing," Arricale asserts. Breen, he says, was given "a tough hand when he replaced Kozlowski in the summer of 2002 and did a fine job. You have to give him credit for doing the right thing by splitting the company up and agreeing to run the least sexy surviving operation, fire and security combined with engineered products."     The primary Wall Street concerns revolve around Tyco's crown jewel, the health-care operation. Revenue growth here slipped to just 2% in the fourth fiscal quarter -- the latest reported -- and operating margins have dropped from 26%-plus a few years ago to just 22.8% in the fiscal year ended Sept. 29, 2006. These developments, according to many analysts, indicate that significant underinvestment in new products over the years is starting to exact a toll.   But T. Rowe Price analyst Peter Bates claims that the situation is hardly irreparable for the unit, which sells everything from gauze pads, laproscopic and electro-surgical devices to advanced suturing products, breathing apparatuses and contrast media for MRI and X-ray imaging.   Yes, the operation was hard hit by product recalls in its respiratory and imaging product areas in early 2006, brought on by Food and Drug Administration complaints over inadequacies in Tyco's production procedures. But the recalls were voluntary, and Bates doesn't see the company suffering  permanent loss of market share in these areas.   For the health-care division still boasts one of the more formidable global marketing systems, one that offers one-stop shopping on an imposing array of products to health-care providers. In fact, strong revenue in the fiscal fourth quarter in both Asia-Pacific (up 14%) and Latin America (up 13%) augur well for the unit's global future. The unit's superior sales organization also permits the company to quickly translate bolt-on acquisitions of promising new technologies into substantial sales gains, according to Bates.   Also, Bates doesn't see the need for increased R&D as proving too punishing for the health-care operation. That tab will rise by $100 million or so over the next four to five years above the current annual R&D spending of about $200 million -- hardly onerous for an operation that last year generated operating income of $2.2 billion. Also, much of the product line consists of so-called hospital consumables -- bed pans, gauze and the like -- which, unlike high-tech devices, don't require heavy research spending.   Finally, Bates expects the unit to dump its operation that makes diaper and incontinence products for the private-label market. This alone will help boost margins, since the diaper unit, which accounts for around 8% of health care's revenues, has been generating operating margins of just around 5% because of soaring plastic-resin prices.   The upshot: Bates sees the health unit eventually trading for $15 to $17 a share, or 17 to 19 times the earnings he projects.   T. Rowe Price also has high hopes for Tyco's soon-to-be liberated electronics business, which last year generated $12.7 billion in revenues and $1.8 billion in operating income. It specializes in connectors, relay cables and wireless components found in everyday products like automobiles, computers and hand-held electronics devices. These products require careful engineering and large-scale production capability. Among other things, a tripling in copper prices in recent years (copper accounts for nearly 10% of electronics' cost base), and production cutbacks in Detroit have retarded the unit's profit growth rate somewhat.   But, according to Bates, these negatives are starting to abate. The Big Three U.S. automakers account for an ever smaller piece of the unit's auto business, with auto demand continuing to grow nicely in Europe and Asia where Tyco has a significant presence. The company is also finally succeeding in putting through some price increases at a time when copper prices are now falling.   And the electronics business figures to benefit in the years ahead from both the surge in the penetration of electronic devices in new cars and a strong global economy that is pushing demand for mobile handsets, consumer electronics and wireless safety-communication equipment. Moreover, at over 4% of annual sales, electronics' R&D spending has been more than adequate, Bates contends. Meantime the unit's operating margins are likely to improve as the company over the next five years boosts the percentage of manufacturing done in low-cost overseas locations to 70 from the current 30 level.   Bates figures the electronics business is worth $12 to $14 a share, on a P/E of 16.5 to 19.   The third prospective Tyco stub will be its fire-and-security unit, along with engineered products and services, businesses that last year had combined revenue of $18.6 billion and operating income of $1.9 billion. Bates attaches much importance to the fact that this is the unit that Breen has decided to run. For, the analyst contends, this is the very business where much remains to be done to "rationalize" the operation, despite many rounds of cost-cutting here by Breen during his four and a half years at the helm of Tyco.   According to Bates, the engineered-products business still has about 200 plants around the globe, churning out pipes, valves and other flow-control equipment both for Tyco's fire-safety systems and other commercial and governmental users. Many of these facilities will eventually be shuttered and consolidated to increase the unit's scale and thereby lower fixed costs and boost margins.   (MORE TO FOLLOW) Dow Jones Newswires  January 06, 2007 00:04 ET (05:04 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: UK PRESS: Renault Eyes UK Low-Cost Market
Story: LONDON (Dow Jones)--Renault (13190.FR), the French carmaker, is looking at the U.K. for a possible launch of the Logan, its bargain-priced, Romanian-born emerging-markets car, in 2008, The FT reports Saturday, citing Renault executive Gerard Detourbet.   If it proceeds, the cars would likely be produced at Renault's joint venture plant in India with Mahindra & Mahindra LTD (500520.BY), the Indian vehicle manufacturer, the FT says.     Newspaper Web site: http://www.ft.com     -London Bureau, Dow Jones Newswires; +44 (0)20 7842 9320     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  January 06, 2007 07:06 ET (12:06 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(1/8) Cleaning Up On Tyco's Breakup -2-
Story: Tyco's fire and security operation, which includes the international brand ADT, has much unfinished business, Bates believes. The consolidation of back office and monitoring facilities continues apace. ADT's account attrition and average revenue per unit are finally starting to improve following the games Kozlowski's management team played with ADT. He gunned growth at ADT by buying willy-nilly new residential and commercial accounts from outside dealers with no attention to the customers' creditworthiness. Cancellations eventually soared, saddling ADT with heavy losses from generating insufficient income to defray heavy upfront installation costs. Likewise, Tyco is still in the early innings of revamping ADT's dealer network in Great Britain and Continental Europe.   In all, the unit containing fire, security and other businesses should trade for $11 to $14 a share, Bates says, with a P/E of 15 to 17.   It remains to be seen if T. Rowe Price will be proven right and much of Wall Street proven wrong. But spinoffs of even ordinary companies often provide upside surprises. Managers perform better with fewer corporate overseers looking over their shoulders and more financial incentives tied to the individual performance of their individual operations.   And surely it's high time for the House that Koz Built to be dismantled.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  January 06, 2007 00:04 ET (05:04 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: UK PRESS: Sita In Running To Acquire Cory Environmental
Story: LONDON (Dow Jones)--Sita Enterprises LTD (512589.BY), the waste management division of Suez (France) (12052.FR), the French energy group, has emerged as a candidate to acquire Cory Environmental, which has been put on the market for around GBP500 million, The Daily Telegraph reported Saturday, citing industry sources.   Sita is reported to be working with UBS on the bid, the newspaper said.    Newspaper Web site: http://www.telegraph.co.uk     -London Bureau, Dow Jones Newswires; +44 (0)20 7842 9320     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  January 06, 2007 06:32 ET (11:32 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: UK PRESS:First Choice Holidays Joins Race For French Rival
Story: LONDON (Dow Jones)--First Choice Holidays PLC (FCD.LN), the tour operator, is understood to be among the leading bidders in the EUR200 million auction of Go Voyages, the French travel group, The Times reported Saturday without citing sources.   It is one of four shortlisted parties that include Duke Street Capital, CDC Enterprise and Financiere Agache, the newspaper reported.      Newspaper Web site: http://www.timesonline.co.uk   -London Bureau, Dow Jones Newswires; +44 (0)20 7842 9320     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  January 06, 2007 06:36 ET (11:36 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(1/8) Research Reports
Story: (From BARRON'S)     Edited by Anita Peltonen   The research reports excerpted here were issued recently by investment firms. Many may be obtained through Thomson Financial at www.thomson.com/financial or 800-638-8241. Some are available in the company-research area of WSJ.com, or through Factiva.com. Some of the reports' issuers have provided, or hope to provide, investment-banking or other services to the companies being analyzed.     Advanced Micro Devices   -- AMD-NYSE     Sell   -- Price 20.35 on Jan. 3   by ThinkEquity Partners     Advanced Micro Devices inventories have suddenly built in the channel, and prices are plummeting. We believe the channel is angry, and PC OEMs are expressing concern about AMD's roadmap (particularly mobile). We fear this will translate into share loss to Intel. With the price war between AMD and Intel re-igniting, we believe AMD has little opportunity of meeting the high expectations for GM and OM it set on its recent analyst day. With capacity building in the channel and the risks of missteps in executing its merger with ATI, we lower our rating to Sell and price target to $15.     Zumiez   -- ZUMZ-NNM     Hold   -- Price 29.54 on Jan. 3   by McAdams Wright Ragen     We think issues related to ZUMZ' rapid pace of expansion and subsequent deleverage in the third quarter are likely to be short-lived. In addition, we believe ZUMZ could show considerable leverage going into the back half of FY07 as square-footage growth returns to more normalized levels and the new stores opened over the past 12 months gain momentum. Should the shares exhibit any weakness, we may reconsider our Hold rating for longer-term investors, as we continue to believe that ZUMZ is one of the best-positioned and well-differentiated concepts in the teen retail space. We are maintaining our $31 target price.     T. Rowe Price   -- TROW-NNM     Buy 2   -- Price 43.77 on Dec. 29   by UBS     We are upgrading T. Rowe Price to Buy 2 from Neutral 2 and taking our price target to $52 from $50. In our view, T. Rowe remains one of the premier firms in the asset- management industry, with a culture second to none, and given the recent pullback in the shares despite solid underlying fundamentals, we view the risk/reward as attractive.     Boyd Gaming Corp   -- BYD-NYSE     Outperform   -- Price 45.31 on Jan. 2   by Bear Stearns     Our new year-end 2007 price target is based on a roll-out to 2008 estimates (similar to other stocks that we cover) and is similarly based on a sum-of-the-parts approach. Our new price target is $55 (previously $50) and implies approximately 20% upside from current levels.   Our 4Q06 EPS estimate of $0.39 is unchanged and is in line with consensus. BYD reports some 4Q results sometime in early February. We continue to recommend BYD for the following reasons: 1) reasonable relative valuation (approximately 9.0x 2008 Ebitda) and 2) a solid development pipeline: Borgata hotel tower expansion (YE07), Florida slots (1Q08), North Las Vegas development (2H09), Blue Chip expansion (1Q08) & Echelon Place (late 2010), which should allow it to grow free cash flows, over time.   We also think that M&A/balance-sheet recapitalizations/private-equity interest in the sector will continue to support current valuation levels for BYD and the sector.     Chattem   -- CHTT-NNM     Outperform   -- Price 50.10 on Jan. 3   by Avondale Partners     Chattem closed the previously announced acquisition of five brands from Pfizer/JNJ. Purchase price of $410 million was in line with expectations and the timing was at or a little ahead of expectations. We are raising our F2007E (Nov.) EPS estimate by +0.25 to $2.67 to reflect accretion from the deal, as previously expected by management....Our preliminary F2008E (Nov.) remains in the $2.60-$2.85 range. Assuming a return of the prospective P/E ratio to the upper teens/20x range as EPS growth accelerates, our 12-18 month price objective is in the mid-$70s.   Chattem is a leading marketer and manufacturer of a variety of branded consumer products, principally over-the- counter health-care and nutritional products. The company is well positioned for continued strong top-line growth. CHTT is in several key niche OTC pharmaceutical categories with benign competition and favorable margins. The company is a very efficient marketer and efficient product innovator. We believe CHTT is on the cusp of a meaningful acceleration in EPS growth.     Cray   -- CRAY-NNM     Buy   -- Price 11.88 on Jan. 3   by Needham & Co.     Under new management (including a new CEO and new leaders in technology, engineering, finance, marketing, operations and customer support) installed in mid-2005, Cray has developed a clear vision and is demonstrating dramatically improved execution in all operational areas, which should position the company for a sustained period of yr/yr growth and improving profitability, in our view. Although quarterly results should remain lumpy, we encourage investors to take an intermediate to long-term view on fundamental improvements at Cray....We are reinstating coverage with a Buy rating and a $15 price target, or 20x our 2008 EPS estimate of 0.73, based primarily on the improving business and financial momentum of the company and our DCF/comparable-company analysis.     Arrow Electronics   -- ARW-NYSE     Outperform   -- Price 32.03 on Dec. 29   by Raymond James     We continue to view Arrow and Avnet (ACT/$26.00/Outperform) as the best mid- cap stories in our space for the following reasons: 1) industry cyclicality has structurally changed, resulting in shorter and more frequent cycles, 2) improving returns on capital due to better asset velocity, 3) greater consistency in free-cash-flow generation due to slower growth and better working-capital management, 4) greater financial flexibility which has spurred debt reduction and M&A activity, 5) both companies are clear leaders in an industry requiring economies of scale and scope, thus suggesting further consolidation, and 6) valuations very attractive at 10-11x P/E and approximately 6.5-7x EV/Ebitda.     Applebee's   -- APPB-NNM     Sell   -- Price 24.67 on Jan. 3   by Bank of America Securities     With Applebee's facing another year of flattish EPS in 2007 and the stock trading at a 21x P/E and at 10x EV/Ebitda, the shares appear overvalued based on the challenging casual-dining environment. The stock has been strong because Breeden Partners (an activist hedge fund with a 5% ownership) has proposed "value-creating" strategies (refranchising units/stopping company-owned growth, etc.) and [has] nominated four candidates for APPB's 12-person board. But we see only limited upside potential at this point, and 15% downside.     Motorola   -- MOT-NYSE     Sector Perform   -- Price 20.56 on Jan. 2   by Pacific Crest Securities     RAZR is beginning to fade: Our most recent checks indicate that the RAZR's reign as the top-selling phone in the United States may have begun to fade quite considerably in the past few weeks of the holiday selling season. While it remains the top seller at three of the top four carriers in the U.S., the phone seems to have fallen below the LG 8300 and Chocolate at Verizon Wireless.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  January 06, 2007 00:05 ET (05:05 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(1/8) Quarterly Mutual Funds Review: Fund -2-
Story: Moszkowski: We've actually never been concerned that they would have significant long-term issues with respect to consolidating the Citigroup deal. When they missed the first couple of quarters, it was because those consolidations were not taking place as quickly or in as orderly a manner as some people would have liked. But in our view, there was never any question that it was on track.     Q: What does concern you?   Moszkowski: They've had some [bad] timing; some of their core products had been underperforming. They haven't been able to realize the promise of that merger to as great an extent as one might have hoped. That's because the Smith Barney [distribution] channel, which is a very productive sales channel, has not been all that receptive to Legg's equity products. Right now, they just don't have a lot of equity products that are particularly in demand. Their fixed-income funds appear to be doing quite well in a multitude of channels, as they have for a long time under Western Asset Management. They also have a little bit of a mix-shift issue, which is what we think affected the third quarter.     Q: What kind of mix shift?   Moszkowski: If assets do not grow or are lost on the equity side and are replaced by an equal amount of assets on the fixed-income side, their assets under management may end up being what you thought they would be. But because of the revenue-sharing arrangements with Western Asset Management, their fixed-income subsidiary, the margin that comes to the bottom line for Legg Mason isn't as attractive with fixed-income assets as it is with equity assets.     Q: Legg has certainly struggled with some of its big equity funds, not just Bill Miller's. On an asset-weighted basis, Legg finished toward the back of the pack last year.   Moszkowski: That's really the source of our concern. At the same time, they have a lot of very good management talent. Sometimes, people have a cold streak.   Mayer: It is an accident of timing; a number of their equity strategies underperformed at the same time. And it just happened to happen as they were accessing this huge distribution potential. So the distribution potential is still there. We just think it may take a little longer to access and exploit than people expect.     Q: What about Janus [JNS], which you rate as neutral? The overall fund performance of that company has improved, hasn't it?   Moszkowski: Actually, they have been improving their performance for 3 1/2 years.   Mayer: Their percentage of four- and five-star funds has continued to improve. At the same time, the flows to the legacy Janus assets haven't really picked up that much. The outflows have improved but the sales maybe haven't improved as much as hoped.   Moszkowski: The recovery has been very sluggish, even though the performance has been better for quite some time.   Mayer: That speaks to more of a brand issue probably, and maybe just some lingering doubts some of the financial advisers out there have about the Janus funds. It is just going to take time. Another laggard in 2006 was Federated Investors [FII], a huge player in the money-market business. The stock was down almost 9% last year. The money-market business isn't that exciting, but it's lucrative, especially if you are a dominant player.   Moszkowski: Federated is a very defensive kind of position because about 75% of its assets are money funds. The product is a bit of a commodity, but, yes, if you have scale -- and they certainly do -- it can be extremely profitable, and their margins have always been fine. But what's going to provoke some real growth in that business? It is usually going to be when the fear/greed pendulum swings more toward fear, and we haven't had a whole lot of that. So they haven't had the kind of asset inflows that other fund groups have had.   Mayer: A lot of people think of Federated as a money-market manager. But if you look at its revenue, a lot comes from equity and fixed-income funds. But only 23% of Federated's stock funds have four and five stars, which is about the lowest level among the public asset managers with big mutual-fund businesses. They had consistent equity and fixed-income fund outflows all year, hurting their revenue growth.     Q: What's the bull case for Federated?   Mayer: With the Fed pausing in its tightening or, at some point, maybe lowering rates, there would be a huge rush of money into institutional money-market funds. That's a possibility. But it is a competitive business now; there are a lot of players in that business. It has become commoditized and a lot of people want those flows.     Q: You have a neutral rating on T. Rowe Price, a very well-regarded company.   Moszkowski: We think that T. Rowe Price is pretty fairly valued.     Q: By our calculations, T. Rowe fetches about 20 times 2007 profit estimates.   Moszkowski: So it is toward the high end of the industry in terms of valuation, and there is nothing depressed about its earnings. So it is not like they trade at a high multiple and depressed earnings that could get a lot better. The issue is really valuation. On the basis of reputation, historical fund performance, and quality and longevity of the management team, you have to give T. Rowe very, very high marks. And it is a big beneficiary of the long-term retirement-savings trend, which helps its 401(k) business.     Q: Over all, then, what's your advice on how to invest in these stocks?   Mayer: Pick your spots. They tend to outperform in an up market and underperform in a down market. So if your outlook is for a fairly good market in '07, then the right companies should do just fine.   Moszkowski: Focus a lot on relative performance, distribution power, flows and reputation. We filter all of that through valuation.   Mayer: In a down market, the more balanced companies should be more defensive, as well, along with the ones with more cash.   Moszkowski: Federated, for sure, as long as the Fed doesn't cut rates again so much that you are pushing a 1% [fed-funds rate].     Q: You have a neutral on Cohen & Steers [CNS], whose shares did spectacularly last year, thanks to being well-positioned in global real-estate investing and having some closed-end funds as well.   Mayer: About 75% of their products are real-estate investment trusts, or REITs. They've been benefiting terrifically by being in REITs.     Q: But aren't they vulnerable to a slowdown in the global real-estate market?   Mayer: Yes, but there are different kinds of real estate. Right now, commercial real estate is pretty strong. There's also a trend around the world of monetizing real estate. Countries are adopting the REIT structure. That probably will continue, regardless of valuations. They are also benefiting from greater recognition of REITs as an asset class with a standard allocation in a portfolio.     Thanks very much.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  January 06, 2007 00:06 ET (05:06 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: =WSJ: Toyota Seen Needing To Rev Up N Amer Mfg Capacity
Story: By Norihiko Shirouzu     Of THE WALL STREET JOURNAL     DETROIT -- Toyota Motor Corp. (TM), which is gearing to pick a site for its eighth North American vehicle assembly plant as early as this month, has no time to waste in manufacturing capacity expansion in the region, and some company insiders say it may soon need to start looking for a site for a ninth plant.   That's because its North American production ratio - a figure that measures how localized and "American" Toyota is by comparing the number of vehicles Toyota builds in North America with its imports from Japan - has been plunging because of surging imports from Japan.   (This story and related background material will be available on The Wall Street Journal Web site, WSJ.com.)   Toyota has publicly said it aims to produce in North America two-thirds of the overall number of vehicles it sells here. Its chairman, Fujio Cho, has said the ratio ideally should reach as high as 75%.   But rising imports have sent Toyota's North American production ratio slipping to 54% in 2006, and Toyota's top brass fears the company may be becoming vulnerable to political backlash. Last November, when CEOs of the three Detroit automakers met with President George W. Bush, they complained about, among other issues, the weak value of the yen. The U.S. automakers contend the undervalued yen gives Japanese competitors a $3,000-to-$9,000 subsidy per vehicle for Japanese exports and the parts used in Japanese-owned U.S. plants.   According to people familiar with the matter, Toyota has narrowed the site search for its eighth plant to three to five locations and could announce its choice as early as this month. Among those locations are Chattanooga, Tenn., and Marion, Ark., they said. Others mentioned by people familiar with the matter included a location near Alamo, Tenn., and a site in North Carolina. The new plant would have annual manufacturing capacity of 200,000 vehicles and start production in 2009 of most likely the next-generation Highlander SUV, these people said.   Some company insiders said Toyota needs to build capacity to manufacture small cars such as the Yaris in order to meet growing demand in both North and South America.   A slipping North American production ratio is ill-timed because Toyota has been mounting a multi-million-dollar ad campaign stressing how "American" it has become here. In magazine ads and on its Web pages featuring American employees in production and sales and product development, the company touts "commitment to investing in the communities we do business," and the number of jobs it has created: it directly employs more than 32,000 Americans, and its dealer and parts suppliers have helped create additional 386,000 jobs in the U.S.   Still, according to an internal Toyota document, Toyota's North American production ratio, or "NAP ratio," will remain around 55% this year and 54% in 2008 and 57%-62% in 2009. It doesn't expect it to recover to 60%-65% levels until 2010 when a No. 8 North American ramps up to its capacity.   Jim Press, the senior most American executive at Toyota, said Toyota's North American production ratio is slipping because of a sudden surge of demand in the U.S. for smaller fuel-efficient cars that coincided with a run-up in gasoline prices last year. The NAP ratio slide is "temporary" as Toyota is meeting an unanticipated rise in demand for small cars which Toyota doesn't produce in North America, he said.   "We are producing more cars here and we are employing more Americans than any of the Asian and European auto makers, and we are committed to expanding our manufacturing footprint here," Mr. Press, a Toyota managing officer, said. Though there is no firm deadline, Mr. Press said he agrees with his boss Mr. Cho that the company should aim to push its North American production ratio as high as 75% "at some point."   That means Toyota might have to begin searching for a site for a ninth North American plant soon, according to the knowledgeable individuals.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  January 06, 2007 11:59 ET (16:59 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: UK PRESS: BSE Shortlists 5 Bourses For Stake Sale
Story: LONDON (Dow Jones)--The Bombay Stock Exchange has shortlisted London Stock Exchange Group PLC (LSE.LN), Nasdaq Stock Market Inc. (NDAQ), Deutsche Borse AG (DB1.XE), NYSE Group Inc. (NYX) and the Singapore stock exchange for the proposed sale of its 26% stake, India's Business Standard reports on its Web site, citing an industry source.   The BSE will also place some equity privately with domestic institutions and banks, provided they don't have their own broking units in line with regulatory guidelines, the newspaper says.   The BSE will offer the stake to a maximum of three strategic investors, and will give preference to overseas bourses that have better technological skills in derivatives, the paper reports.     Newspaper Web site: http://www.business-standard.com     -London Bureau, Dow Jones Newswires; +44 (0)20 7842 9320     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  January 06, 2007 07:34 ET (12:34 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Nissin Foods Founder Dead At 96; Invented Instant Noodles
Story: TOKYO (AP)--Momofuku Ando, the Japanese inventor of instant noodles, has died, according to Nissin Food Products Co. (2897.TO), the company he founded. He was 96.   Ando died of a heart attack on Friday, Nissin said in a statement posted Saturday on its corporate Web site.   He was born in Taiwan in 1910, when the island was under Japanese colonial rule. He moved to Japan in 1933, according to Japan's daily Mainichi newspaper.   Faced with food shortages in post World War II Japan, Ando developed the idea that a quality, convenient noodle product would help feed the masses. He founded Nissin in 1948.   In 1958, "Chicken Ramen," the first instant noodle product, was introduced after many trials. Following its success, the company continued to add innovative products, including "Cup Noodle" in 1971.   "The Momofuku Ando Instant Ramen Museum" opened in 1999 in Ikeda City in western Japan commemorating his inventions.   The company's products even went into space when Japanese astronaut Soichi Noguchi took instant noodles in a pouch called "Space Ram" on his 2005 mission on board the U.S. space shuttle Discovery.   Ando was a keen promoter of developing food for space travel, Nissin said.   Ando gave a 30-minute speech at the company's New Year ceremony and enjoyed Chicken Ramen for lunch with Nissin employees on Thursday before falling ill, Japan's largest daily Yomiuri said.   Ando is survived by his wife Masako, two sons and a daughter.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  January 06, 2007 11:13 ET (16:13 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(1/8) Commodities Corner: Tin: It's The New Bling
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Andrea Hotter   Tin, that most pedestrian of metals, is getting the type of attention usually reserved for more glamorous elements.   Investor interest in the notoriously illiquid market is at its highest levels since the cartel years of the 1980s, with contract highs forcing metals-industry analysts to dust off their notebooks and assess a market largely ignored by researchers. London Metal Exchange tin ended 2006 up 78% on the year. It peaked at $11,850 a metric ton on Dec. 29, andhas been hovering near that price since.   Indonesian supply worries triggered the latest gains, with the world's largest producer facing a sharp government-led clampdown on production. And the situation doesn't seem about to change, leaving tin's price outlook bright, indeed.   The problems started in October, when Indonesia's government moved overnight to shut down 20 to 25 illegal, independent tin smelters, saying they were operating without the necessary permits and had failed to pay royalties.   Those smelters account for about half of what's produced by the country's two key producers, PT Timah (ticker: TINS.Jakarta) and PT Koba Tin. It's a relatively small amount when taken in a global perspective, but the fear is that the hiatus could spread to the country's other tin operations. Indonesia produces 120,000-130,000 tons a year out of a total global production of 370,000 tons in 2006, UBS analyst Robin Bhar says.   PT Koba, which operates at Indonesia's prime tin-ore deposit on Bangka island, has already been dragged into the limelight by the government clampdown. Local media reports suggested the company's license was revoked because it's been buying tin ore illegally mined by the small-scale miners on the island, an accusation its majority owner, Malaysia Smelting (5916.Kuala Lumpur), vehemently denies.   A plan to award permits to qualified smelters is on the table, but analysts say it'll likely take time to agree on and even longer to implement. In the meantime, there's little new production expected. The situation took the market by surprise and has forced analysts to revise their estimates for the market balance going forward.   It's not just the Indonesian supply shock that has forced the tin-price boom; the gains have come at a time of rampant demand for the metal, which has surged by more than 30% in the past four years. Driven at first by a booming electronics industry, demand for tin has rocketed since new European laws requiring lead to be phased out of solders came into force mid-2006.   The alternative solders are all rich in tin, with an average content of more than 96%, against the traditional 60%, analysts say. Such is the growth in this area that solders are now outpacing tin plate to become tin's major end-use.   Analysts warn that if the supply situation reverts, the recent additional buying interest could wane and tin prices could fall. But for the time being, the market looks set to keep its luster.   ---   ANDREA HOTTER is the commodities news editor for Dow Jones Newswires in London.   ---   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  January 06, 2007 00:05 ET (05:05 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(1/8) Editorial Commentary: The Royal CEO
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Thomas G. Donlan   Most people do not win the privilege of being right -- absolutely, overwhelmingly right, so right that the rest of the world acknowledges its fault and gives that right-minded person everything it took away before.   Steve Jobs has earned and enjoyed that privilege. He founded Apple Computer, based on his personal vision of personal computing. He feuded with its board of directors and financiers over his vision. He was ejected. In the wilderness, he founded another computer company, and then a computer-animation company, while Apple Computer was foundering under his successors.   Apple, about to fail, brought Jobs back with apologies, which might have been satisfying enough, except that he had been having new ideas while he was gone. To turn the iPod into a new line of business might have been satisfying enough, but Jobs turned it into a new industry, a new medium in a media-drenched age. The iPod, iTunes and further iDevices and iServices have nearly overshadowed the Apple personal computer, even as Jobs oversaw a revolution in Apple Computer's technology and software.   All of this, to a degree rarely seen in enormous modern businesses, was Jobs' personal achievement. He deserves personal credit. Indeed, he has earned whatever reward he chooses.   Why then, are the unproductive vultures of corporate democracy and securities regulation circling over Apple's headquarters in Cupertino, Calif.?   At the worst, Steve Jobs directed his company to issue him stock options on favorable terms, without bothering with the silly legal necessity of having a board meeting to approve it. Then-still at the worst, for none of this is admitted or proven -- Jobs directed some minions to cover up by creating false records of a fictitious board meeting to repair the damage.   The company says Jobs had nothing to do with these improper actions, that he didn't profit from them, and that it was all a dreadful mistake. Jobs has apologized for letting such things happen on his watch, although he knew nothing about them.   Of all this, the only important words are these: "his company."   More than 100 executives have resigned in disgrace from a variety of public companies for similar violations, but the case of Apple and Jobs most plainly is a case of fatuous nonsense.   A public company is public in the sense that the company sells bits of paper called equity, and accedes to the polite fiction that the shareholders own the company.   In reality, what the shareholders own is a ticket to ride on the ship that others have built, others navigate, others load, others steer. Properly seen, what they own is a claim on a share of the assets, after liabilities are paid, if the company is dissolved while solvent, and they own a claim to an equal share of the dividends if any are paid.   In the meantime, the shareholders have the right to sell their shares in the marketplace at the same price that any other shareholder could sell them in the same quantity. The new buyer is assured that the shares he buys are as good as any others.   Unfortunately, the legalistic pretense that shareholders really own and should direct the affairs of public companies has been transformed over the past couple of decades into the absurdity that they should vote on the company's major decisions, and be told of all the company's minor ones.   The shareholder rights movement views corporations as representative democracies with serious and immutable responsibilities to stock owners, in which board members are elected to govern and to represent the interests of shareholders. This view has been injected into legislation and regulation to the point where litigation and prosecution are nearly inevitable in a company run for the benefit of those who created it or keep it running well.   If the worst be true at Apple, it is still legislation and regulation that are at fault, not Steve Jobs. If he wanted to rig some options to pay himself an extra $20 million, the shareholders riding along with his success also benefited to the tune of billions.   Nothing would be different if the board and the corporate bureaucrats had managed all the details in accordance with the best standards imposed by a bunch of busybodies and bureaucrats.   If the worst be true at every other company in America where options have been manipulated, the proper standards still should be profits and share price, not the size or composition or timing of the compensation package.   A corporation is not a democracy or a republic. It is better thought of as a monarchy with a board of directors as the monarch's privy council.   How does this square with the human rights and property rights of shareholders?   Shareholders are not serfs. They have the right to leave the kingdom by selling their shares.   Are shareholders not entitled to the information they need to judge their investments?   They have a voice in the marketplace, and a CEO will provide the information necessary to attract their capital to his enterprise.   Are they not entitled to throw the king out the window when he fails to serve them well?   Ultimately, they have that right, but they would not be wise to use it too often. The best reason for defenestration of the monarch is the bankruptcy of the corporation. When a company like Apple does very well, the shareholders shouldn't rebel.   Unfortunately, those who would stir up the shareholders to throw out successful CEOs because their options paid off too well are like the Jacobins of the French Revolution. They wish the people would throw off their old masters, to make room for the new ones: the Jacobins.   ---   Editorial page editor THOMAS G. DONLAN receives e-mail at tg.donlan@barrons.com.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  January 06, 2007 00:09 ET (05:09 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Saudi Sabic Completes $685M Buy Of Huntsman's UK Assets-2
Story: Sabic first announced its intention to purchase Salt Lake City-based Huntsman's U.K. assets in September.   Under the deal, Sabic has acquired petrochemical and aromatics facilities at Wilton and North Tees.   The Saudi company will also complete by the end of 2007 the construction of a 400,000-tonne a year low-density polyethylene, or LDPE, plant in Wilton, Teeside in the U.K.   -By Oliver Klaus, Dow Jones Newswires, +9714 229 2806 Oliver.Klaus@dowjones.com   Copyright (c) 2006 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  January 06, 2007 07:29 ET (12:29 GMT)

Headline: =WSJ: Mitsubishi Motors Hopes New Models Reverse US Slump
Story: By Norihiko Shirouzu     Of THE WALL STREET JOURNAL     DETROIT - Mitsubishi Motors Corp.'s (7211.TO) U.S. business keeps shrinking, but don't count out the Japanese auto maker yet.   Mitsubishi is looking to start the new year by unveiling the next-generation Mitsubishi Lancer sedan during the media preview of the North American International Auto Show in Detroit, which starts Sunday. According to people familiar with its plans, the company also may announce in Detroit Monday a plan to sell a diesel-powered Lancer by around 2010.   (This story and related background material will be available on The Wall Street Journal Web site, WSJ.com.)   Moreover, those people said Mitsubishi's North American business will likely make money on an operating basis - about Y5 billion - in the year ending March 31 for the first time in four years. The last time Mitsubishi made money in North America was the year ended March 2003 when the Tokyo-based company made Y101.6 billion in operating income.   It wasn't clear whether Mitsubishi would continue to make money in the new fiscal year beginning on April 1. A company spokesman declined to comment.   For the year ending March 31, the company returns to profitability in North America thanks in part to its more disciplined business strategy under which it curtailed sales to vehicle rental operators and other fleet customers, which offer limited profitability.   The people familiar with the situation said the new Lancer, which is expected to hit dealer showrooms in the spring and is due to be unveiled at a press conference at the Detroit Auto Show Monday, has grown in size compared with the current model it replaces. It uses the same vehicle underpinnings for the Outlander car-SUV crossover Mitsubishi began selling in the U.S. in November 2006.   Also scheduled for an unveiling in Detroit Monday is a concept car Mitsubishi calls "the Prototype X," which the knowledgeable sources said is a thinly disguised high-performance version of the redesigned Lancer sedan. The model is expected to be named the Lancer Evolution.   The Lancer Evolution should arrive in dealer showrooms in early 2008.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  January 06, 2007 12:10 ET (17:10 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(1/8) Asian Trader: China Stocks Look Ready For A Correction
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Leslie P. Norton   Is the big correction in China shares starting at last? Late Friday, China boosted its bank-reserve requirements for the fourth time since June, and it could raise interest rates by mid-year to rein in its boom.   In trading later in New York, Chinese shares fell sharply. The ishares FTSE/Xinhua (ticker: FXI) exchange-traded fund was down 6%, while big-caps like PetroChina (PTR), China Life (LFC) and China Mobile (CHL) swooned.   Quite a reversal from last year'senormous gains, which took place as China reformed its share markets, economic growth climbed, the currency snapped higher, and Chinese investors began to part with some of their $2 trillion in savings.   These conditions created "a long-term sustainable bull market for China," albeit one with "lots of trading rotational opportunities," maintains Lou Gerken of Gerken Capital, whose GCA Greater China Fund was up 24% last year. As the Hang Seng China Enterprises index rose 14% in November and 21% in December, people grew fearful of selling: "You're seeing very limited shorting because you can't bet against the liquidity flow," says Tim McKenna, managing director at CLSA Asia Pacific Markets. "It's very frothy."   Still, investors took profits on financials and real estate, amid fear that China would clamp down on frothy property markets, and rotated into laggard auto companies like Brilliance China Automotive (CBA), and into power companies like Huaneng Power (HNP), whose tax rate may fall as China moves toward a unified tax system.   Despite that rotation, China's big banks, all Hong Kong-listed, are still expensive -- "like Nasdaq in late 1999," says Rajiv Jain of Vontobel Asset Management.   "At current levels, we expect a significant correction, particularly in financial stocks," says Shu Yin Lee, the manager of Dalton Greater China, a Shanghai-based hedge fund that rose 28% in 2006. "The state-owned banks are now trading at over three times book value in Hong Kong and four times on the A-share market" dominated by local investors, "and by market capitalization, Industrial & Commercial Bank of China is now larger than HSBC!"   Early last week, Merrill Lynch's emerging-markets strategist, Michael Hartnett, said that Chinese stocks had run up late last year on huge inflows into stock funds that coincided with a December pause in the initial public offering calendar. "The liquidity bubbled straight through to equity prices," Hartnett wrote clients.   A Bank of Japan rate hike could rein in Japanese enthusiasm for sending capital abroad. China now trades at 17.2 times earnings, with expected earnings growth of 10%, versus 12.5 times for global emerging markets, where profits are expected to rise by 14.4%.   Today's China premium is 38% -- more than four times the average since 1994. How far does Hartnett see stocks falling? About 10% in the next four to six weeks. After all, in 2003, Chinese stocks rose 175%. In 2004, as night follows day, they fell.     Pity poor Sanyo Electric, the world's largest maker of rechargeable batteries. Its shares (6764.Tokyo) were halved last year and recently traded at 154 yen after a barrage of bad news: a forecast of its third annual loss amid more job cuts (Sanyo shut 10% of its business units in the past year to boost returns), a credit-rating cut, a battery recall and slumping sales of mobile phones and digital cameras. Recently, it also disclosed that it would exit LCD-panel production. The company has already considered numerous restructuring measures, sales, spinoffs, and partial strategic alliances.   Many investors hate the stock, but it may yet fall further. Last march, Sanyo issued 429 million convertible preferred shares. "We do not expect holders of the preferred shares to hold them indefinitely," wrote Merrill analyst Hitoshi Kuriyama.   To Mark Hake of Hake Capital, a small-cap value specialist, the best-case scenario is that Sanyo achieves a return on equity of 4.5% by March 2008. Sanyo's shares now trade at 2.25 times book value, "extremely generous for a company that will, at best, make a 4.5% return on equity," says Hake. Sanyo also trades at 15 times cash flow, nearly twice the industry average.   David Benwell of Clocktower Capital remains short Sanyo shares: "The current price doesn't include the potentially large dilution from the convertible, and the business is likely to get more competitive," warns Benwell. "I think even 100 yen would be a full valuation."     The numbers are in: The best Japan fund for 2006 was ProFunds UltraJapan (UJPIX), up 14%; the top Pacific ex-Japan fund was iShares MSCI Singapore (EWS), up 46%; and the No. 1 Pacific fund was Eaton Vance Asia Small Company (EVASX), up 47%.   ---   The Emerging Markets Table now is online (www.barrons.com).   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  January 06, 2007 00:06 ET (05:06 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: UK PRESS:BAT Chief Pours Cold Water On Gallaher Bid Talk
Story: LONDON (Dow Jones)--British American Tobacco PLC (BTI), the world's second-largest cigarette company, says that big acquisitions are unnecessary for the group to meet its growth targets, The Times reports Saturday, citing Chief Executive Paul Adams.   "We don't see a lot of attractiveness at the moment for us in the usual suspects when it comes to acquisitions," Adams says, The Times reports.     Newspaper Web site: http://www.timesonline.co.uk     -London Bureau, Dow Jones Newswires; +44 (0)20 7842 9320     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  January 06, 2007 07:07 ET (12:07 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: : 2007 Is Flying: Midwest Airlines Offers Sale Fares on Travel Through Sept. 30
Story: MILWAUKEE, Jan. 6 /PRNewswire-FirstCall/ -- Continuing its long tradition of providing customers comfort, great value and exceptional fares, Midwest Airlines (Amex: MEH) is offering sale fares for travel through Sept. 30, 2007. The fares are available Sunday, Jan. 7 through midnight Central time     Tuesday, Jan. 16, 2007. No advance purchase is required. Sale fares are available from most cities served by Midwest, including Duluth/Superior -- its newest destination, with service beginning March 4.     Travelers who book roundtrip travel online at midwestairlines.com and use promo code SAVE5DOLLARS will save an additional $5 off advertised sale fares. To make reservations, visit midwestairlines.com, call Midwest Airlines Reservations at 800-452-2022 (in Milwaukee, 414-570-7000) or contact a travel consultant.     Included in the fare sale is travel on Midwest Airlines and Midwest Connect. Midwest Airlines Signature Service features seating altered from standard coach to a roomier two-by-two configuration; Midwest Airlines Saver Service provides low-fare flights to popular leisure destinations. Midwest Connect offers connections throughout the Midwest Airlines and Midwest Connect route system, and point-to-point service in select markets.          Travel Monday through Saturday for the lowest sale fares; slightly higher  fares apply for travel on Sunday. A Friday- or Saturday-night stay is  required; travel to/from Las Vegas requires a two-night stay. Sample one-way  fares apply to travel through Feb. 14.
