Headline: Barron's(1/8) Bed Bath & An Intriguing Bargain
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Andrew Bary   WHEN INVESTORS TALK ABOUT THE country's best retailers, names likeTarget, Costco Wholesale, Abercrombie & Fitch and Neiman-Marcus inevitably come up. A lesser-known company that deserves inclusion in that group is Bed Bath & Beyond, which has one of the industry's best growth records and among the highest profit margins.   Since Bed Bath & Beyond went public in 1992, its revenues have increased 30-fold and its profits are up by a factor of 35. The company's shares (ticker: BBBY), at around 39, are up by a similar amount, having risen from a split-adjusted initial-public-offering price of $1.   Wall Street, however, is cautious on Bed Bath, as its fans on Main Street call the housewares emporium, amid concerns that demand for linens, tableware, small appliances and other home furnishings is slowing. After its quarterly earnings release in late December, the company issued mildly disappointing financial guidance for its coming fiscal year starting in March, calling for 10% growth in both sales and earnings per share, below the 12% gain in operating earnings anticipated for the current fiscal year. This prompted analysts to trim their fiscal 2008 estimates by about a dime, to $2.40 a share. The stock dipped two points on the news, and now stands no higher than it did in 2003.   But fans of the tight-lipped retailer argue its shares are attractive, and could rise into the high-40s if Bed Bath & Beyond tops what many deem to be conservative financial guidance for the coming fiscal year. "Bed Bath & Beyond is one of the best retailers in the country," says Mario Cibelli, who heads Marathon Partners, a New York investment firm that holds the stock.   The company has a net, after-tax profit margin of 9%, double that of Target (TGT) and better than Kohl's (KSS), Home Depot (HD) and other retailing luminaries. Bed Bath & Beyond maintains those enviable margins despite bombarding consumers with coupons that offer 20% off a single item in its stores. The coupons drive traffic to the stores, which maintain an everyday low-price policy and rarely run sales.   "The company's ability to generate double-digit earnings growth year in and year out is appealing in a market that might not be able to do that," says Robert Zagunis, co-portfolio manager of the Jensen Portfolio (JENSX), a mutual fund that holds the stock.   Cibelli argues the stock's risk has diminished as the company's price/earnings ratio has come down. Bed Bath & Beyond now trades for 18 times projected profits of $2.15 a share in the fiscal year ending in February, and 16 times estimated earnings of $2.40 in the year ending in February 2008. The company's P/E based on future earnings was more than 30 in 2003.   With a lower multiple, says Cibelli, the stock "ought to appreciate in line with earnings." Other retailers, including Home Depot, Kohl's and Wal-Mart (WMT), have suffered from a similar erosion in P/E multiples.   Bed Bath could be a target for a leveraged buyout, given its cash-rich balance sheet, high returns and moderate market capitalization of around $11 billion. The company has more than $1 billion of cash and equivalents, equal to almost $4 a share, and no debt.   The retailer's enterprise value (equity value, less cash) of $10 billion is equal to about nine times projected 2007 pre-tax cash flow. While many private-equity buyers don't like paying more than eight or nine times annual cash flow, chances are they'd be willing to pay 10 times cash flow or more in this case, given the company's history of superior results, and its promising outlook. A buyer might have to cut back on store expansion to free up cash.     Bed Bath's chief competitor, Linens 'n Things, was taken private in a 2006 LBO by a group including Apollo Management. That deal hasn't gone well so far. Linens 'n Things was a weak No. 2 to Bed Bath & Beyond prior to the LBO, and it has trailed Bed Bath in sales growth since going private. It now is operating in the red due to onerous interest expense. Bed, Bath & Beyond should benefit if Linens 'n Things continues to struggle.   So far, Bed Bath & Beyond's financially conservative management team, led by chief executive Steven Temares, 48, and co-chairmen and co-founders Warren Eisenberg and Leonard Feinstein, have shown no inclination to alter radically the company's capital structure. Eisenberg, 76, and Feinstein, 69, who founded Bed Bath & Beyond in 1971, together hold about 4% of the company's stock-enough to influence potential acquirers but not enough to block a well-funded bid.   An alternative to an LBO could be a large, debt-funded share buyback. In a December report, David Bianco, the equity strategist at UBS Securities, put Bed Bath high on the list of companies that could make a big share repurchase. The company announced a $1 billion share-buyback program later that month, which is expected to be completed over two years.   "Management is pretty old-school on capital allocation," Cibelli says. The company hasn't paid a dividend since going public, preferring to use profits for growth initiatives and buybacks.   Bed Bath & Beyond counts some well-regarded value investors in its shareholder base, including Ruane Cunniff, manager of the Sequoia Fund (SEQUX), and Davis Selected Advisers. Two large hedge funds, Maverick Capital and Lone Pine Capital, established positions in the third quarter.   Bed Bath & Beyond is run much like a private company. Management says little to Wall Street and rarely meets with investors. The company held a conference call after its earnings release last month, but took no questions. Company officials declined to talk to Barron's and may not speak publicly until the next profit release in April. Proximity to Wall Street isn't an excuse for the lack of communication; Bed Bath is based about 15 miles from Manhattan, in Union, NJ. The company's view seems to be that its results should do the talking, while management burnishes its reputation for tending fanatically to the details of running the business.   Bed, Bath & Beyond operates 796 stores in 47 states, up from 34 stores in 1992. It remains the leader in its niche despite competition from Linens 'n Things as well as Target, Wal-Mart and Sears. Its fiscal '07 sales are expected to hit $6.5 billion, up 12% from the prior year, versus an estimated $2.4 billion for Linens 'n Things.   The chain is known for giving store managers considerable leeway in what they stock, allowing for differences in regional tastes. It has a keen focus on customer service, and even accepts competitors' coupons. Shop at the Bed Bath & Beyond on Manhattan's Upper East Side in May or June, and the store will ship purchases to summer homes throughout the region. Store managers are expected to be on the floor, rather than in their offices, during peak weekend shopping hours.   One blot on management is that it engaged in option backdating for many years. The company announced completion of its options review in October and said it would take a $74 million non-cash charge.   Bed Bath is still a growth company. It is expected to add 72 stores, a 10% expansion, in the current fiscal year, bringing the store base to 813. Another 70 stores are expected to open in fiscal '08. The company has said it sees the potential for 1,300 domestic stores.   New-store openings haven't cannibalized existing stores, which are likely to register sales growth of about 4% in fiscal '07 and '08, after rising roughly 4.5% in each of the past two fiscal years. Linens 'n Things, by contrast, saw comparable-store sales contract 1% in the first nine months of 2006. A weaker housing market hasn't crimped Bed Bath sales, as some on the Street feared.   Bed Bath & Beyond operates two smaller-and promising-retail chains, Harmon and Christmas Tree Shops, which was purchased in 2003 for about $200 million. Neither contributes much yet to the company's bottom line; indeed, investors have been disappointed by the subdued pace of expansion at both chains. There are 38 Harmon stores, which sell health and beauty-care items, and 35 Christmas Tree stores, which, contrary to the name, sell more than just Christmas items. They offer low-priced housewares and novelties, ranging from wine glasses to photo albums and porcelain dolls.     Wall Street's chief concern is decelerating growth at Bed, Bath & Beyond stores. After '07 guidance was released last month, Credit Suisse retailing analyst Gary Balter cut his rating on the stock to Neutral from Outperform, citing weakening operating margins and slowing revenue growth.   The company's expenses are up by about two percentage points, relative to last year, prompting fears that growth is becoming more expensive. Such concerns are reflected in the stock, however.   For more than a decade after its IPO, Bed, Bath & Beyond doubled earnings every three years. Those days are over, but double-digit annual profit growth looks doable. Combine that with a cash-rich balance sheet, an excellent management team, a reasonable stock-market valuation and the possibility of an LBO, and Bed Bath & Beyond could reward patient investors.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  January 06, 2007 00:04 ET (05:04 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: China Greentown To Buy Out Beijing Ppty Unit For CNY17.5M
Story: HONG KONG (Dow Jones)--Property developer Greentown China Holdings Ltd. (3900.HK) said Saturday it will buy out one of its property units for 17.5 million yuan ($2.2 million).   The company said it has agreed to buy the 35% interest it doesn't already own in Beijing Xingye Wanfa Real Estate Development Co. from Xinshidai Properties Co.   Prior to the transaction, Greentown China owned 65% of Beijing Xingye, which develops low-rise apartments in Beijing.   Greentown China was listed in Hong Kong in July last year. According to its listing prospectus, Greentown China had a total land bank of 8.6 million square meters, including projects under development and those held for future development, making it one of China's largest residential property developers.     -By Aries Poon, Dow Jones Newswires; 852-2832-2332; aries.poon@dowjones.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  January 06, 2007 03:11 ET (08:11 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(1/8) Medifast's Executive Ranks Thin
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Neil A. Martin   One is the rejection last September by Diabetes Care, the respected journal of the American Diabetes Association, of a Johns Hopkins study on the effectiveness of the Medifast dietary regimen in helping diabetics. That study has been a bedrock of the company's marketing effort and a contributor to the rise in its stock since mid-2005. The rejection, which Medifast hasn't disclosed publicly, came after a peer review by weight-loss experts. The publication declined to explain its reasoning.   More recently, Barron's has learned, Medifast's board has become concerned about Internet postings, under the name bradmed@verizon.net, in support of Medifast on the Yahoo! Finance message board. People in a position to know say that this is a pseudonym and that MacDonald was the author of these messages.   When Barron's asked the former Marine colonel, who is remaining with the company as an adviser and executive chairman of its board, whether he was "bradmed," he denied it. "There are a lot of Brads out there," he said, and "I don't make a practice of that."   But, according to knowledgeable people, company directors reprimanded MacDonald in mid-December after learning of a Barron's inquiry into the postings, and told him to stop posting messages, fearing, among other things, that this could violate "fair disclosure" regulations.   Medifast shares declined 6% to 11.60 on Friday following disclosure of MacDonald's planned departure.   Barron's raised questions about the Johns Hopkins study last fall ("Medifast Diet Disorder" Sept. 4, 2006). At the time, we asked several weight-loss researchers to review a one-page abstract of the study by the Johns Hopkins Weight Management Center. They concluded that it needed more work and believed it added little to the body of research on weight-loss management."It looked like a very flawed study," said one researcher.   Medifast officials have variously referred to Johns Hopkins as "the gold standard" of the medical industry and credited "studies like that as being the cornerstone of our business" by reinforcing "clinically proven" and "scientifically proven" claims in its advertising and public relations.   They also credited the June 2005 announcement of the Hopkins results as helping Medifast shares surge 600%, to a peak of 21, in June 2006. Asked about the status of the Hopkins study last week, President and Chief Financial Officer Michael S. McDevitt, who will take over as CEO in March, said "the researchers are pursuing full paper publication in a leading medical journal."   The Internet messages pose still other questions. From May 23 through Dec. 29, there were 10 postings under the bradmed@verizon.net name. They called Yahoo! chat room readers' attention to an "interesting and balanced" profile of MacDonald, in Baltimore Smart CEO magazine; extended a congratulatory "Semper Fi" to all MED supporters and investors;" attacked Barron's as "the National Enquirer of the Financial Press;" denounced Taglich Brothers, a "second-rate" paid-for-research firm that MacDonald hired but then fired after it rated his company's stock Underperform; and defended his wife's sales of more than $2.7 million in stock in November and early December. (MacDonald and his family own about 8% of Medifast's shares).   Despite the board's reprimand to MacDonald a couple of weeks earlier, bradmed@verizon. net appeared again on Dec. 29, posting a message lauding the 140% return in the company's stock price during the year. (Medifast shares soared from $5.24 on Dec. 30, 2005, to close the year at $12.57.)   After these new messages appeared, Barron's queried McDevitt about whether MacDonald was behind them and received an ambiguous e-mail response: "Mr. MacDonald as an individual and the largest single shareholder of Medifast, Inc. has taken positions in many forums in the public domain to provide publicly available and factual information or to clarify misperceptions, misinformation and false rumors in the marketplace." He added: "I believe that stockholders have the right to express historical and publicly available information in all forums."   But even if a CEO weren't disclosing private company information, corporate governance experts say failure to identify himself as an executive of the company could be a problem. "In a worst-case scenario, it could be considered a fraud on the market if you are giving incomplete information and in my mind it is incomplete per se if you don't say where it is coming from by hiding your identity," says Nell Minow, editor and co-founder of The Corporate Library, a corporate governance group.   Louis Navellier of Reno-based Navellier & Associates is the single largest institutional Medifast holder, with about 4.4% of the 13.5 million shares outstanding. Navellier, a former regulator with the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, agrees that anonymous Internet postings by a CEO are a "no-no." He calls Medifast "a bunny stock-always hopping around."   In light of the latest developments, the bunny should be hopping frantically over the next few days.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  January 06, 2007 00:09 ET (05:09 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: WSJ(1/8) Street Smart: They're Ba-ack...
Story: (From THE WALL STREET JOURNAL)     By Megan Barnett   [Still wary of Internet stocks? Get over it. We found that three that shot up 49 percent in five months -- and are poised for continued growth.]     IT HAS BEEN only five months since we closed our eyes, took a deep breath and wrote this first sentence for a story: "Internet stocks are back." While the wounds may still seem fresh for investors who were burned by the sector's freefall a few years ago, those who jumped in at our recommendation in September should be feeling whole again. Our portfolio of three Internet stocks shot up 49 percent, blowing the healthy 15 percent return for the Standard & Poor's 500 right out of the water.   A lot has happened to drive those returns. Google bought 19-month-old YouTube for $1.6 billion; Microsoft released Vista, its long-awaited operating system; and Internet advertising revenues rose to a new record high of $4.2 billion in the third quarter, up 33 percent from 2005. While it's still premature to dust off our 1999 party caps, investors in Internet stocks should sleep well at night. "Without question, we are still very early in seeing economic returns from these stocks," says Robert Hagstrom, portfolio manager of the Legg Mason Growth Trust fund, who holds several Internet stocks in his fund.   Our top performer was Akamai Technologies, the leading player in the content-distribution business. It does the behind-the-scenes work on your downloads by capturing content, like a digital song, on its server and delivering it to your computer. As broadband usage grows, so do digital downloads, a fact that has helped push Akamai's shares up 64 percent. But investors should hold on tight, because the ride's not over yet. "We'd be hard-pressed to say it's cheap right now, but we think it's a great long-term holding," says Tara Hedlund, portfolio manager for the Turner New Enterprise fund.   To be sure, "cheap" is not a word many people are throwing around these days in talking about these Internet stocks. Shares of InterActiveCorp soared 48 percent since we recommended it. Investors don't seem troubled that Chief Executive Barry Diller was declared the highest-paid CEO in the country in 2005 -- estimates of his compensation run up to $295 million. "Those who have been with Barry since day one have made a lot of money," Hagstrom says. Its diversified portfolio of properties, including LendingTree, Ticketmaster and the search engine Ask.com, provide stable growth, Hagstrom says. He especially likes InterActive's "enormous cash flows."   Adobe Systems brought up the rear of the portfolio with its 35 percent gain. It currently trades at 29 times 2007 earnings, and Kevin Landis, manager of the Firsthand Technology Leaders fund, says it "can reasonably go to 35" during the next year, making it a $47 stock. "This is a healthy, solid business," he says.     Revisiting John Lynch     IN OUR MAY ISSUE, we introduced you to the fast-talking, wheeling-and-dealing computer-equipment trader John Lynch in "Rebel Rouser." As the head of Asset Recovery Center, Lynch buys used hardware for pennies on the dollar and resells it at a premium. At the time, Cisco equipment was in high demand, selling at a 50 to 75 percent markup. The demand and pricing Lynch sees can be a good indicator for investors: Since our May issue, Cisco stock has run up 29 percent. And now? Lynch says the story on his end is much the same today as it was back in May. Sounds like a buy to us. (AKAM)      32.54       53.38     64.0  InterActiveCorp (IACI)    24.38       36.13     48.2  Total Portfolio               -           -     49.0  S&P 500                       -           -     14.7    SOURCE: BLOOMBERG     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  January 06, 2007 00:09 ET (05:09 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Raytheon Missile Systems Replaces Striking Factory Workers
Story: TUCSON, Ariz. (AP)--Raytheon Missile Systems has started replacing factory workers who went on strike two months ago after rejecting a contract offer.   A union spokesman called the hires "an insult to existing employees."   Production at the factory has risen above pre-strike levels and some projects are ahead of schedule since nearly 2,000 machinists went on strike Nov. 5, Raytheon spokeswoman Sara Hammond said.   But the company can't keep using its engineers as factory workers indefinitely. The plant makes the Javelin anti-tank missile, the Tomahawk missile, air-to-air missiles and ship self-protection missiles.   Hammond said the company was hiring assembly workers and custodians, but wouldn't say how many.   Bobby Martinez, International Association of Machinists and Aerospace Workers Local 933's directing business representative, called Raytheon's announcement a strategic ploy.   "This is a company tactic to pressure our members into accepting their offer," he said.   Representatives of the union and Raytheon have separate meetings scheduled with a federal mediator next week.   Around 90% of the union's members voted to reject the contract offer because "it's a below-industry-standards offer and there are some uncertainties in the language of the contract," Martinez said.   Strikers have said their main concerns are the rising cost of health insurance and minimal raises for the highest-paid employees covered by the contract.   Raytheon Missile Systems, a division of Raytheon Co. (RTN), is Southern Arizona's largest private employer with more than 11,000 employees.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  January 06, 2007 08:17 ET (13:17 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(1/8) The Electronic Investor: Checking Your Funds' Fitness
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Kathy Yakal   The fund researcher (www.morningstar.com) recently bolstered its already substantial capabilities. It has doubled the number of holdings an individual portfolio can accommodate to 100 mutual funds or stocks, 20 bonds and 20 cash positions. Morningstar also has created 50 new data points (items such as five-year fund-price highs) and added to its performance-analysis tools.   You can now track multiple share classes, as well as more foreign and over-the-counter securities. New sections of international and closed-end fund coverage have appeared, and the depth and range of hedge-fund information has increased. There's more analyst-report coverage, and a remodeled stock page, as well as new video reports. This is a substantial upgrade for Morningstar, and it's not done yet; stay tuned.     Personal-finance information has been available free on AOL's Website (www.aol.com) for some time. As far as mutual-fund coverage is concerned, AOL does that at which both it and Yahoo! Finance excel: pulling tools and data from the best suppliers on the Web and organizing them so they're easy to use.   AOL's mutual-fund-educational sections are some of the best we've seen. Comprehensive but easy-to-understand chapters explain what mutual funds are and why they can be beneficial; what yields, returns, fees and loads mean and how to read relevant tables. There's also a section on mutuals' new cousins, exchange-traded funds. In the chapter on open- and closed-end funds, the site includes calculators that help you compute variables like the effect of fees on performance.   Among AOL's licensed contributors: SmartMoney.com; Businessweek.com; TheStreet.com and Marketwatch.com. AOL hosts its own message boards for mutual funds, some of which are pretty active.     Smartmoney.com, whose parent companies are Dow Jones, which publishes Barron's, and Hearst, is a more likely venue for those seeking original content. Much of it is free, but the best stuff is behind a subscriber wall (two-week free trial; $59/year for delayed quotes, $109/year for real-time). Non-subscribers still have access to some of the site's mutual-fund tools and data, including the top 25 funds.   Subscribers get more mutual-fund content. A sophisticated screening tool draws on a database of more than 12,000 funds, letting you choose from more than 60 criteria like length of portfolio-manager tenure. SmartMoney.com also assembles its own screens and posts them periodically.   Mutual-fund content alone wouldn't justify SmartMoney's subscription price. Its data, tools and excellent staff analysis of the overall market do.     MSN Money (moneycentral.msn.com), on the other hand, doesn't charge for any of its content. But the site offers less written analysis and no options for real-time data. Still, if you want to screen for funds down to the last possible variable, there's no better place. You can sift through hundreds of characteristics such as 12-month yield to shape your research. Pre-fabricated, non-customized screens are also provided, as is a step-by-step research Wizard for novice investors.   MSN Money's Deluxe Screener is overkill for a lot of investors; you can find simpler ones at sites like Yahoo! Finance (finance.yahoo.com/funds). New since we last visited Yahoo!'s mutual-fund center is an interactive guide, a great place for beginning fund investors to hang out. Tutorials from INVESTools are featured here, as are educational materials from sources like the Vanguard Group. Yahoo! also posts fundamental and some technical analysis of funds, as well as information on fund families and top performers.   This is a great venue for a little of everything. If you prefer more analysis, visit MarketWatch. It's full of commentary, tools and data. (MarketWatch is also owned by Dow Jones.)   When should you sell a fund? Fundalarm.com alerts you when it thinks it's time to hit the exit.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  January 06, 2007 00:09 ET (05:09 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: UK PRESS: Tote Raises Financing For GBP405 Mln Buyout
Story: LONDON (Dow Jones)--U.K. bank Lloyds TSB has agreed to finance a GBP405 million joint bid for state-run betting operator the Tote by management and a racing consortium, The Independent reported Saturday, citing industry sources.   The racing consortium includes Jockey Club Racecourses, The Racehorse Owners Association and the Racecourses Association, The Independent reported. The consortium members, while initially wary of the heavily debt-backed bid, are now understood to be warming to the plan, according to the report.   Newspaper Web site: http://www.independent.co.uk      -London Bureau, Dow Jones Newswires; +44 (0)20 7842 9320     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  January 06, 2007 05:58 ET (10:58 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: SINGAPORE PRESS:CityDev Sells 70% Of New Apartment Units
Story: SINGAPORE (Dow Jones)--City Developments Ltd. (C09.SG) sold over 70% of the units at its newest Singapore condominium Friday, The Business Times reported.   Of the One Shenton project's 341 units, 100 were released for sale initially as part of Friday's "soft launch," but investors - mainly those who purchased entire floors of the building - drove the total much higher, the paper said Saturday.   The units measure between 517 square feet and 9,085 square feet, and have asking prices between S$1,500 per square foot and S$2,000 psf.   Some of the penthouse units on the condominium's upper floors may fetch even higher prices.   The average price for mass market condominiums in 2006 was around S$650 psf while the average price for high-end projects was between S$1,600 psf and S$1,700 psf, according to real estate firm Knight Frank Singapore.   CityDev expects construction of One Shenton to be complete in 2011.     Newspaper Web site:   http://business-times.asia1.com.sg     -By Singapore Bureau; Dow Jones Newswires; 65-6415-4150; djnews.singapore.bureau@dowjones.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  January 06, 2007 04:15 ET (09:15 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.
